paragraphs.text: Mr Speaker, Honourable Members, we have great tasks before us. I say, with all seriousness, that it is rarely that human beings have such an opportunity for service to their fellows.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Reframes the moment as rare historical opportunity for service to humanity, elevating the vote from political action to moral calling.

paragraphs.text: Mr Speaker, for my part, I can only re-echo the words of a great man: 'Man's dearest possession is life, and since it is given him to live but once, he must so live as not to be besmeared with the shame of a cowardly existence and trivial past, so live that dying he might say: all my life and all my strength were given to the finest cause in the world -- the liberation of mankind.'
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Invokes a great man's words about living for liberation of mankind, positioning the motion as alignment with humanity's highest purpose.

paragraphs.text: Mr Speaker, 'Now God be thank'd, Who has match'd us with His hour!' I beg to move.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Concludes with a final invocation ('God be thank'd, Who has match'd us with His hour') and formal motion—sealing action as divinely ordained.

title: Our march to freedom is irreversible
speaker: Nelson Mandela
summary: Vision contrasting apartheid's destructiveness with democratic future demanding mass action and determination.
introduction: Nelson Mandela delivered this speech in February 1990, shortly after his release from 27 years of imprisonment under South Africa's apartheid regime. Speaking to a massive crowd of ANC supporters and international observers, Mandela addressed the nation and world at an extraordinary historical juncture: the government had legalized the ANC, released him, and signaled readiness to negotiate. His audience included activists who had sustained the anti-apartheid struggle for decades, white South Africans watching a formerly imprisoned Black leader claim a national platform, and international supporters who had campaigned for his freedom. Mandela faced a delicate challenge: energizing his movement while avoiding inflammatory language that could derail negotiations, celebrating freedom while acknowledging the work ahead. His credibility was immense; he had refused multiple conditional offers of release to maintain principles. The speech marked the beginning of South Africa's transition from state terror to constitutional democracy.

paragraphs.text: Friends, Comrades and fellow South Africans. I greet you all in the name of peace, democracy and freedom for all. I stand here before you not as a prophet but as a humble servant of you, the people. Your tireless and heroic sacrifices have made it possible for me to be here today. I therefore place the remaining years of my life in your hands ... Today the majority of South Africans, black and white, recognize that apartheid has no future. It has to be ended by our own decisive mass action in order to build peace and security. The mass campaign of defiance and other actions of our organization and people can only culminate in the establishment of democracy.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Establishes the historical moment and announces the decisive action required to end apartheid.

paragraphs.text: The apartheid destruction on our subcontinent is incalculable. The fabric of family life of millions of my people has been shattered. Millions are homeless and unemployed. Our economy lies in ruins and our people are embroiled in political strife.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Vivid inventory of apartheid's destruction: shattered families, homelessness, unemployment, economic ruin.

paragraphs.text: Our resort to the armed struggle in 1960 with the formation of the military wing of the ANC, Umkhonto we Sizwe (Spear of the Nation), was a purely defensive action against the violence of apartheid. The factor which necessitated the armed struggle still exists today. We have no option but to continue ...
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Explains the harsh conditions that made armed struggle necessary and still require continued resistance.

paragraphs.text: Negotiations on the dismantling of apartheid will have to address the overwhelming demand of our people for a democratic, non-racial and unitary South Africa.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Negotiations must dismantle apartheid structures, implicitly rejecting reformist half-measures that preserve white monopoly.

paragraphs.text: There must be an end to white monopoly on political power, and a fundamental restructuring of our political and economic systems to ensure that the inequalities of apartheid are addressed and our society thoroughly democratized.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Describes the fundamental transformation needed: end to white political monopoly and thorough democratization.

paragraphs.text: It must be added that Mr de Klerk himself is a man of integrity, who is acutely aware of the dangers of a public figure not honouring his undertakings. But as an organization, we base our policy and strategy on the harsh reality we are faced with. And this reality is that we are still suffering under the policies of the Nationalist government.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Credits de Klerk's good intentions while warning that current reality proves those intentions are insufficient.

paragraphs.text: Our struggle has reached a decisive moment. We call on our people to seize this moment, so that the process towards democracy is rapid and uninterrupted.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Declares the struggle at a decisive moment and calls the people to seize the opportunity immediately.

paragraphs.text: We have waited too long for our freedom! We can no longer wait. Now is the time to intensify the struggle on all fronts. To relax our efforts now would be a mistake which generations to come will not be able to forgive. The sight of freedom looming on the horizon should encourage us to redouble our efforts. It is only through disciplined mass action that our victory can be assured.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Urgent call to intensify struggle on all fronts with disciplined mass action to assure victory.

paragraphs.text: We call on our white compatriots to join us in the shaping of a new South Africa. The freedom movement is a political home for you, too. We call on the international community to continue the campaign to isolate the apartheid regime. To lift sanctions now would be to run the risk of aborting the process towards the complete eradication of apartheid.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Mobilizes white compatriots and international community as coalition partners in the transformation.

paragraphs.text: Our march to freedom is irreversible. We must not allow fear to stand in our way. Universal suffrage on a common voters' roll in a united, democratic and non-racial South Africa is the only way to peace and racial harmony.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Affirms the irreversibility of the march to freedom and the concrete form of the democratic future.

paragraphs.text: In conclusion I wish to go to my own words during my trial in 1964. They are as true today as they were then. I quote:
paragraphs.comment: Transitional passage introducing the climactic quotation from Mandela's 1964 trial testimony.

paragraphs.text: 'I have fought against white domination and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunity. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and to achieve. But if needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die. Amandla (power)!'
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Anchors the vision in decades of personal sacrifice and willingness to die for democratic ideals.

title: A more perfect union
speaker: Barack Obama
summary: Race speech addressing racial divisions as choice between unity or continued polarization to solve common challenges.
introduction: Barack Obama delivered this speech in Philadelphia on March 18, 2008, during his campaign for the U.S. presidency. The occasion emerged from controversy over recordings of his former pastor, Reverend Jeremiah Wright, whose sermons contained provocative critiques of American racism and military policies. Wright's comments threatened Obama's campaign viability among white voters, and his political opponents sought to weaponize them. Rather than disavow Wright entirely or dismiss racial grievances, Obama chose a rare rhetorical path: addressing America's racial history directly while calling for transcendence of racial division. Speaking before an audience in the room, millions watching on television, and the global media, Obama articulated a vision of American democracy that acknowledged historical injustice without being imprisoned by it. The speech demonstrated sophisticated political leadership at an inflection point where mishandling could have derailed his candidacy or deepened national polarization.

paragraphs.text: 'We the people, in order to form a more perfect union.' Two hundred and twenty-one years ago, in a hall that still stands across the street, a group of men gathered and, with these simple words, launched America's improbable experiment in democracy. Farmers and scholars; statesmen and patriots who had travelled across an ocean to escape tyranny and persecution finally made real their declaration of independence at a Philadelphia convention that lasted through the spring of 1787. The document they produced was eventually signed but ultimately unfinished. It was stained by this nation's original sin of slavery, a question that divided the colonies and brought the convention to a stalemate until the founders chose to allow the slave trade to continue for at least twenty more years, and to leave any final resolution to future generations.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama opens by anchoring the present moment in the founding contradiction of American democracy: a union premised on equality yet built on the original sin of slavery.

paragraphs.text: Of course, the answer to the slavery question was already embedded within our Constitution -- a Constitution that had at its very core the ideal of equal citizenship under the law; a Constitution that promised its people liberty, and justice, and a union that could be and should be perfected over time.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The Constitution's promise of equal citizenship exists as an ideal embedded within the founding document, establishing the gap between promise and practice.

paragraphs.text: And yet words on a parchment would not be enough to deliver slaves from bondage, or provide men and women of every colour and creed their full rights and obligations as citizens of the United States. What would be needed were Americans in successive generations who were willing to do their part -- through protests and struggle, on the streets and in the courts, through a civil war and civil disobedience and always at great risk -- to narrow that gap between the promise of our ideals and the reality of their time.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Words alone were never sufficient; successive generations had to actively close the gap between the Constitution's ideals and the lived reality of injustice.

paragraphs.text: This was one of the tasks we set forth at the beginning of this campaign -- to continue the long march of those who came before us, a march for a more just, more equal, more free, more caring and more prosperous America. I chose to run for the presidency at this moment in history because I believe deeply that we cannot solve the challenges of our time unless we solve them together -- unless we perfect our union by understanding that we may have different stories, but we hold common hopes; that we may not look the same and we may not have come from the same place, but we all want to move in the same direction -- towards a better future for our children and our grandchildren.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Obama presents his campaign as a continuation of that generational march, grounded in the belief that Americans with different stories can hold common hopes and move together.

paragraphs.text: This belief comes from my unyielding faith in the decency and generosity of the American people. But it also comes from my own American story.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: His conviction in American decency derives from personal faith and from his own lived American story, grounding the abstract in the autobiographical.

paragraphs.text: I am the son of a black man from Kenya and a white woman from Kansas. I was raised with the help of a white grandfather who survived a Depression to serve in Patton's Army during World War II and a white grandmother who worked on a bomber assembly line at Fort Leavenworth while he was overseas. I've gone to some of the best schools in America and lived in one of the world's poorest nations. I am married to a black American who carries within her the blood of slaves and slave owners -- an inheritance we pass on to our two precious daughters. I have brothers, sisters, nieces, nephews, uncles and cousins, of every race and every hue, scattered across three continents, and for as long as I live, I will never forget that in no other country on Earth is my story even possible.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama's multiracial biography embodies the complexity of America's racial history, making him a living testament to both the nation's contradictions and its possibilities.

paragraphs.text: It's a story that hasn't made me the most conventional candidate. But it is a story that has seared into my genetic makeup the idea that this nation is more than the sum of its parts -- that out of many, we are truly one.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: His unique story has shaped his conviction that the nation is more than the sum of its parts, a personal source for his political vision.

paragraphs.text: Throughout the first year of this campaign, against all predictions to the contrary, we saw how hungry the American people were for this message of unity. Despite the temptation to view my candidacy through a purely racial lens, we won commanding victories in states with some of the whitest populations in the country. In South Carolina, where the Confederate Flag still flies, we built a powerful coalition of African Americans and white Americans ... it has only been in the last couple of weeks that the discussion of race in this campaign has taken a particularly divisive turn.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The campaign's early success across racial lines is contrasted with the divisive turn prompted by the Wright controversy, establishing the immediate crisis.

paragraphs.text: On one end of the spectrum, we've heard the implication that my candidacy is somehow an exercise in affirmative action; that it's based solely on the desire of wide-eyed liberals to purchase racial reconciliation on the cheap. On the other end, we've heard my former pastor, Reverend Jeremiah Wright, use incendiary language to express views that have the potential not only to widen the racial divide, but views that denigrate both the greatness and the goodness of our nation; that rightly offend white and black alike.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Both ends of the spectrum — dismissing his candidacy as mere affirmative action and Wright's incendiary language — represent forms of racial thinking that widen division.

paragraphs.text: I have already condemned, in unequivocal terms, the statements of Reverend Wright that have caused such controversy. For some, nagging questions remain. Did I know him to be an occasionally fierce critic of American domestic and foreign policy? Of course. Did I ever hear him make remarks that could be considered controversial while I sat in church? Yes. Did I strongly disagree with many of his political views? Absolutely -- just as I'm sure many of you have heard remarks from your pastors, priests or rabbis with which you strongly disagreed.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama acknowledges he knew Wright's controversial views and heard contentious remarks in church, drawing a parallel to congregants who disagree with their own religious leaders.

paragraphs.text: But the remarks that have caused this recent firestorm weren't simply controversial. They weren't simply a religious leader's effort to speak out against perceived injustice. Instead, they expressed a profoundly distorted view of this country -- a view that sees white racism as endemic, and that elevates what is wrong with America above all that we know is right with America; a view that sees the conflicts in the Middle East as rooted primarily in the actions of stalwart allies like Israel, instead of emanating from the perverse and hateful ideologies of radical Islam.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Wright's worldview — seeing white racism as endemic and elevating America's failures above its achievements — is identified as a profoundly distorted and ultimately counterproductive frame.

paragraphs.text: As such, Reverend Wright's comments were not only wrong but divisive, divisive at a time when we need unity; racially charged at a time when we need to come together to solve a set of monumental problems -- two wars, a terrorist threat, a falling economy, a chronic health care crisis and potentially devastating climate change; problems that are neither black or white or Latino or Asian, but rather problems that confront us all.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Wright's divisive comments come precisely at a moment requiring unity to confront shared national problems that transcend racial categories.

paragraphs.text: Given my background, my politics, and my professed values and ideals, there will no doubt be those for whom my statements of condemnation are not enough. Why associate myself with Reverend Wright in the first place, they may ask? Why not join another church? And I confess that if all that I knew of Reverend Wright were the snippets of those sermons that have run in an endless loop on the television and YouTube, or if Trinity United Church of Christ conformed to the caricatures being peddled by some commentators, there is no doubt that I would react in much the same way.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama addresses the question of why he stayed in Wright's church, noting that a full condemnation of snippets misrepresents the complexity of his relationship.

paragraphs.text: But the truth is, that isn't all that I know of the man. The man I met more than twenty years ago is a man who helped introduce me to my Christian faith, a man who spoke to me about our obligations to love one another; to care for the sick and lift up the poor. He is a man who served his country as a US Marine; who has studied and lectured at some of the finest universities and seminaries in the country, and who for over thirty years led a church that serves the community by doing God's work here on Earth -- by housing the homeless, ministering to the needy, providing day care services and scholarships and prison ministries, and reaching out to those suffering from HIV/AIDS.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama describes the actual Wright he knows: a man of faith, service, and community, not reducible to the inflammatory sermon excerpts circulated in media.

paragraphs.text: In my first book, Dreams from My Father, I described the experience of my first service at Trinity:
paragraphs.comment: This is a transitional sentence introducing a quoted passage from Obama's first book about his experience at Trinity United Church of Christ.

paragraphs.text: That has been my experience at Trinity. Like other predominantly black churches across the country, Trinity embodies the black community in its entirety -- the doctor and the welfare mom, the model student and the former gang-banger. Like other black churches, Trinity's services are full of raucous laughter and sometimes bawdy humour. They are full of dancing, clapping, screaming and shouting that may seem jarring to the untrained ear. The church contains in full the kindness and cruelty, the fierce intelligence and the shocking ignorance, the struggles and successes, the love and yes, the bitterness and bias that make up the black experience in America.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Trinity embodies the full complexity of the black community — its joys and struggles, its love and its bitterness — reflecting the full reality of the African-American experience.

paragraphs.text: And this helps explain, perhaps, my relationship with Reverend Wright. As imperfect as he may be, he has been like family to me. He strengthened my faith, officiated my wedding, and baptized my children. Not once in my conversations with him have I heard him talk about any ethnic group in derogatory terms, or treat whites with whom he interacted with anything but courtesy and respect. He contains within him the contradictions -- the good and the bad -- of the community that he has served diligently for so many years.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Wright's place in Obama's life as a near-familial figure explains why he cannot simply disown him, while acknowledging Wright's own human contradictions.

paragraphs.text: I can no more disown him than I can disown the black community. I can no more disown him than I can my white grandmother -- a woman who helped raise me, a woman who sacrificed again and again for me, a woman who loves me as much as she loves anything in this world, but a woman who once confessed her fear of black men who passed by her on the street, and who on more than one occasion has uttered racial or ethnic stereotypes that made me cringe.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The parallel between disowning Wright and disowning his white grandmother — who harbored racial fears yet loved him deeply — illustrates that imperfect people are woven into the fabric of American life.

paragraphs.text: These people are a part of me. And they are a part of America, this country that I love. Some will see this as an attempt to justify or excuse comments that are simply inexcusable. I can assure you it is not. I suppose the politically safe thing would be to move on from this episode and just hope that it fades into the woodwork. We can dismiss Reverend Wright as a crank or a demagogue ...
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: These flawed people are part of Obama and part of America; dismissing them entirely would be politically safe but dishonest about the complexity of race in this country.

paragraphs.text: But race is an issue that I believe this nation cannot afford to ignore right now. We would be making the same mistake that Reverend Wright made in his offending sermons about America -- to simplify and stereotype and amplify the negative to the point that it distorts reality.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Race is an issue the nation cannot afford to ignore, because simplifying and stereotyping — the same mistake Wright made — distorts reality rather than confronting it.

paragraphs.text: The fact is that the comments that have been made and the issues that have surfaced over the last few weeks reflect the complexities of race in this country that we've never really worked through -- a part of our union that we have yet to perfect. And if we walk away now, if we simply retreat into our respective corners, we will never be able to come together and solve challenges like health care, or education, or the need to find good jobs for every American.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The racial divisions surfaced by the controversy reflect unresolved complexities in the American union; retreating into corners forecloses any progress on shared challenges.

paragraphs.text: Understanding this reality requires a reminder of how we arrived at this point. As William Faulkner once wrote, 'The past isn't dead and buried. In fact, it isn't even past.' We do not need to recite here the history of racial injustice in this country. But we do need to remind ourselves that so many of the disparities that exist in the African-American community today can be directly traced to inequalities passed on from an earlier generation that suffered under the brutal legacy of slavery and Jim Crow. Segregated schools were, and are, inferior schools; we still haven't fixed them, fifty years after Brown v. Board of Education, and the inferior education they provided, then and now, helps explain the pervasive achievement gap between today's black and white students.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The historical record of racial injustice — segregated and inferior schools, the persistent achievement gap — is traced as a direct cause of present-day racial disparities.

paragraphs.text: Legalized discrimination -- where blacks were prevented, often through violence, from owning property, or loans were not granted to African-American business owners, or black homeowners could not access FHA mortgages, or blacks were excluded from unions, or the police force, or fire departments -- meant that black families could not amass any meaningful wealth to bequeath to future generations. That history helps explain the wealth and income gap between black and white, and the concentrated pockets of poverty that persist in so many of today's urban and rural communities.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Legalized discrimination in property, lending, employment, and public services systematically prevented black families from building intergenerational wealth, explaining contemporary economic gaps.

paragraphs.text: A lack of economic opportunity among black men, and the shame and frustration that came from not being able to provide for one's family, contributed to the erosion of black families -- a problem that welfare policies for many years may have worsened. And the lack of basic services in so many urban black neighbourhoods -- parks for kids to play in, police walking the beat, regular garbage pick-up and building code enforcement -- all helped create a cycle of violence, blight and neglect that continues to haunt us.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The erosion of economic opportunity for black men fed cycles of family instability and urban neglect that continue to shape present realities.

paragraphs.text: This is the reality in which Reverend Wright and other African-Americans of his generation grew up. They came of age in the late fifties and early sixties, a time when segregation was still the law of the land and opportunity was systematically constricted. What's remarkable is not how many failed in the face of discrimination, but rather how many men and women overcame the odds; how many were able to make a way out of no way for those like me who would come after them.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Wright's generation came of age under segregation, which contextualizes their anger as a response to systematic oppression rather than mere grievance.

paragraphs.text: But for all those who scratched and clawed their way to get a piece of the American Dream, there were many who didn't make it -- those who were ultimately defeated, in one way or another, by discrimination. That legacy of defeat was passed on to future generations -- those young men and increasingly young women who we see standing on street corners or languishing in our prisons, without hope or prospects for the future. Even for those blacks who did make it, questions of race, and racism, continue to define their worldview in fundamental ways. For the men and women of Reverend Wright's generation, the memories of humiliation and doubt and fear have not gone away; nor has the anger and the bitterness of those years. That anger may not get expressed in public, in front of white co-workers or white friends. But it does find voice in the barbershop or around the kitchen table. At times, that anger is exploited by politicians, to gin up votes along racial lines, or to make up for a politician's own failings.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: The legacy of defeat and the persistent anger it generates have political consequences — exploited by politicians and expressed privately — making it a live force in current American life.

paragraphs.text: And occasionally it finds voice in the church on Sunday morning, in the pulpit and in the pews. The fact that so many people are surprised to hear that anger in some of Reverend Wright's sermons simply reminds us of the old truism that the most segregated hour in American life occurs on Sunday morning. That anger is not always productive; indeed, all too often it distracts attention from solving real problems; it keeps us from squarely facing our own complicity in our condition, and prevents the African-American community from forging the alliances it needs to bring about real change. But the anger is real; it is powerful; and to simply wish it away, to condemn it without understanding its roots, only serves to widen the chasm of misunderstanding that exists between the races.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Black anger surfaces in Sunday sermons partly because American life remains so deeply segregated; while real and understandable, that anger can distract from collective problem-solving.

paragraphs.text: In fact, a similar anger exists within segments of the white community. Most working- and middle-class white Americans don't feel that they have been particularly privileged by their race. Their experience is the immigrant experience -- as far as they're concerned, no one's handed them anything, they've built it from scratch. They've worked hard all their lives, many times only to see their jobs shipped overseas or their pension dumped after a lifetime of labour. They are anxious about their futures, and feel their dreams slipping away; in an era of stagnant wages and global competition, opportunity comes to be seen as a zero sum game, in which your dreams come at my expense. So when they are told to bus their children to a school across town; when they hear that an African-American is getting an advantage in landing a good job or a spot in a good college because of an injustice that they themselves never committed; when they're told that their fears about crime in urban neighbourhoods are somehow prejudiced, resentment builds over time.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Working-class white Americans experience their own legitimate economic anxieties, and when they feel those anxieties are dismissed or blamed on racial preferences, resentment builds.

paragraphs.text: Like the anger within the black community, these resentments aren't always expressed in polite company. But they have helped shape the political landscape for at least a generation. Anger over welfare and affirmative action helped forge the Reagan Coalition. Politicians routinely exploited fears of crime for their own electoral ends. Talk show hosts and conservative commentators built entire careers unmasking bogus claims of racism while dismissing legitimate discussions of racial injustice and inequality as mere political correctness or reverse racism.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: White racial resentments have shaped American politics for a generation, exploited by politicians and commentators who channeled them into opposition to civil rights remedies.

paragraphs.text: Just as black anger often proved counterproductive, so have these white resentments distracted attention from the real culprits of the middle-class squeeze -- a corporate culture rife with inside dealing, questionable accounting practices, and short-term greed; a Washington dominated by lobbyists and special interests; economic policies that favour the few over the many. And yet, to wish away the resentments of white Americans, to label them as misguided or even racist, without recognizing they are grounded in legitimate concerns -- this too widens the racial divide, and blocks the path to understanding.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Both black anger and white resentment serve as distractions from the actual sources of economic insecurity — corporate greed, lobbyists, and policies favoring the wealthy few.

paragraphs.text: This is where we are right now. It's a racial stalemate we've been stuck in for years. Contrary to the claims of some of my critics, black and white, I have never been so naïve as to believe that we can get beyond our racial divisions in a single election cycle, or with a single candidacy -- particularly a candidacy as imperfect as my own.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: This is the diagnosis: a racial stalemate, years in the making, that Obama has never naively believed could be dissolved in a single election cycle.

paragraphs.text: But I have asserted a firm conviction -- a conviction rooted in my faith in God and my faith in the American people -- that working together we can move beyond some of our old racial wounds, and that in fact we have no choice if we are to continue on the path of a more perfect union.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Obama asserts his conviction — rooted in faith in God and the American people — that moving beyond old racial wounds is both possible and necessary.

paragraphs.text: For the African-American community, that path means embracing the burdens of our past without becoming victims of our past. It means continuing to insist on a full measure of justice in every aspect of American life. But it also means binding our particular grievances -- for better health care, and better schools, and better jobs -- to the larger aspirations of all Americans -- the white woman struggling to break the glass ceiling, the white man who's been laid off, the immigrant trying to feed his family. And it means taking full responsibility for our own lives -- by demanding more from our fathers, and spending more time with our children, and reading to them, and teaching them that while they may face challenges and discrimination in their own lives, they must never succumb to despair or cynicism; they must always believe that they can write their own destiny.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: For the African-American community, the path forward requires binding particular grievances to the broader aspirations of all Americans while taking responsibility for one's own destiny.

paragraphs.text: Ironically, this quintessentially American -- and yes, conservative -- notion of self-help found frequent expression in Reverend Wright's sermons. But what my former pastor too often failed to understand is that embarking on a programme of self-help also requires a belief that society can change.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Authentic self-help requires belief that society can change, meaning personal responsibility and structural reform are not opposites but complements.

paragraphs.text: The profound mistake of Reverend Wright's sermons is not that he spoke about racism in our society. It's that he spoke as if our society was static; as if no progress has been made; as if this country -- a country that has made it possible for one of his own members to run for the highest office in the land and build a coalition of white and black, Latino and Asian, rich and poor, young and old -- is still irrevocably bound to a tragic past. But what we know -- what we have seen -- is that America can change. That is true genius of this nation. What we have already achieved gives us hope -- the audacity to hope -- for what we can and must achieve tomorrow.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Wright's error was treating America as static — ignoring the genuine progress that has already been made, including the very candidacy Wright helped inspire.

paragraphs.text: In the white community, the path to a more perfect union means acknowledging that what ails the African-American community does not just exist in the minds of black people; that the legacy of discrimination -- and current incidents of discrimination, while less overt than in the past -- are real and must be addressed. Not just with words, but with deeds -- by investing in our schools and our communities; by enforcing our civil rights laws and ensuring fairness in our criminal justice system; by providing this generation with ladders of opportunity that were unavailable for previous generations. It requires all Americans to realize that your dreams do not have to come at the expense of my dreams; that investing in the health, welfare and education of black and brown and white children will ultimately help all of America prosper.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: For the white community, the path forward requires acknowledging that racial discrimination is real and structural, and investing in opportunity for all Americans.

paragraphs.text: In the end, then, what is called for is nothing more, and nothing less, than what all the world's great religions demand -- that we do unto others as we would have them do unto us. Let us be our brother's keeper, Scripture tells us. Let us be our sister's keeper. Let us find that common stake we all have in one another, and let our politics reflect that spirit as well.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: The ultimate call is grounded in the moral imperative shared by all religions: to be our brother's and sister's keeper, recognizing our common stake in one another.

paragraphs.text: For we have a choice in this country. We can accept a politics that breeds division, and conflict, and cynicism. We can tackle race only as spectacle, as we did in the OJ trial -- or in the wake of tragedy, as we did in the aftermath of Katrina -- or as fodder for the nightly news. We can play Reverend Wright's sermons on every channel, every day and talk about them from now until the election, and make the only question in this campaign whether or not the American people think that I somehow believe or sympathize with his most offensive words. We can pounce on some gaffe by a Hillary supporter as evidence that she's playing the race card, or we can speculate on whether white men will all flock to John McCain in the general election regardless of his policies.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Obama lays out the false choice: continuing a politics of division and spectacle, reducing the election to racial grievance and distraction rather than addressing real problems.

paragraphs.text: We can do that.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: The blunt acknowledgment that America can choose the path of division — 'We can do that' — gives the false promise its full weight before rejecting it.

paragraphs.text: But if we do, I can tell you that in the next election, we'll be talking about some other distraction. And then another one. And then another one. And nothing will change.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Choosing distraction guarantees that nothing changes: each election cycle will produce a new distraction while the underlying problems go unaddressed.

paragraphs.text: That is one option. Or, at this moment, in this election, we can come together and say, 'Not this time.' This time we want to talk about the crumbling schools that are stealing the future of black children and white children and Asian children and Hispanic children and Native American children. This time we want to reject the cynicism that tells us that these kids can't learn; that those kids who don't look like us are somebody else's problem. The children of America are not those kids, they are our kids, and we will not let them fall behind in a twenty-first century economy. Not this time.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: The alternative — 'Not this time' — is a collective declaration that Americans can choose to come together and talk honestly about the crumbling schools and opportunities stolen from all children.

paragraphs.text: This time we want to talk about how the lines in the Emergency Room are filled with whites and blacks and Hispanics who do not have healthcare; who don't have the power on their own to overcome the special interests in Washington, but who can take them on if we do it together.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Coming together also means confronting a healthcare system that fails working Americans of all races, a problem only solvable through collective action.

paragraphs.text: This time we want to talk about the shuttered mills that once provided a decent life for men and women of every race, and the homes for sale that once belonged to Americans from every religion, every region, every walk of life. This time we want to talk about the fact that the real problem is not that someone who doesn't look like you might take your job; it's that the corporation you work for will ship it overseas for nothing more than a profit.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: The real economic threat is not workers of other races but corporate decisions to ship jobs overseas, requiring Americans to unite around shared economic interests rather than racial division.

paragraphs.text: This time we want to talk about the men and women of every colour and creed who serve together, and fight together, and bleed together under the same proud flag. We want to talk about how to bring them home from a war that never should've been authorized and never should've been waged, and we want to talk about how we'll show our patriotism by caring for them, and their families, and giving them the benefits they have earned.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Americans of every color who serve together in uniform embody the unity that Obama envisions, and bringing them home honorably is a shared obligation of citizenship.

paragraphs.text: I would not be running for President if I didn't believe with all my heart that this is what the vast majority of Americans want for this country. This union may never be perfect, but generation after generation has shown that it can always be perfected. And today, whenever I find myself feeling doubtful or cynical about this possibility, what gives me the most hope is the next generation -- the young people whose attitudes and beliefs and openness to change have already made history in this election.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Obama's confidence that the vast majority of Americans want this more perfect union is embodied in the next generation, whose openness to change has already made history.

paragraphs.text: There is one story in particular that I'd like to leave you with today -- a story I told when I had the great honour of speaking on Dr King's birthday at his home church, Ebenezer Baptist, in Atlanta.
paragraphs.comment: Transitional sentence introducing the closing story of Ashley Baia, signaling a shift from argument to narrative illustration.

paragraphs.text: There is a young, twenty-three-year-old white woman named Ashley Baia who organized for our campaign in Florence, South Carolina. She had been working to organize a mostly African-American community since the beginning of this campaign, and one day she was at a roundtable discussion where everyone went around telling their story and why they were there.
paragraphs.comment: The story of Ashley Baia begins: a young white woman organizing in a predominantly African-American community, present at a roundtable discussion of why people joined the campaign.

paragraphs.text: And Ashley said that when she was nine years old, her mother got cancer. And because she had to miss days of work, she was let go and lost her health care. They had to file for bankruptcy, and that's when Ashley decided that she had to do something to help her mom.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Ashley's story begins with concrete hardship — her mother's cancer, job loss, loss of healthcare, bankruptcy — the very economic vulnerabilities Obama has been describing.

paragraphs.text: She knew that food was one of their most expensive costs, and so Ashley convinced her mother that what she really liked and really wanted to eat more than anything else was mustard and relish sandwiches. Because that was the cheapest way to eat.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Ashley's sacrifice of eating mustard and relish sandwiches for a year to save money makes the abstract reality of economic hardship viscerally personal.

paragraphs.text: She did this for a year until her mom got better, and she told everyone at the roundtable that the reason she joined our campaign was so that she could help the millions of other children in the country who want and need to help their parents too.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Ashley's motivation for joining the campaign — to help the millions of other children in similar circumstances — scales the personal story into a collective concern.

paragraphs.text: Now Ashley might have made a different choice. Perhaps somebody told her along the way that the source of her mother's problems were blacks who were on welfare and too lazy to work, or Hispanics who were coming into the country illegally. But she didn't. She sought out allies in her fight against injustice.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Ashley could have chosen racial blame — accepting the story that her mother's problems were caused by lazy welfare recipients or undocumented immigrants — but she rejected that false promise.

paragraphs.text: Anyway, Ashley finishes her story and then goes around the room and asks everyone else why they're supporting the campaign. They all have different stories and reasons. Many bring up a specific issue. And finally they come to this elderly black man who's been sitting there quietly the entire time. And Ashley asks him why he's there. And he does not bring up a specific issue. He does not say health care or the economy. He does not say education or the war. He does not say that he was there because of Barack Obama. He simply says to everyone in the room, 'I am here because of Ashley.'
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: The elderly black man's simple answer — 'I am here because of Ashley' — is the vision of hope made concrete: a moment of cross-racial recognition built on shared humanity rather than ideology.

paragraphs.text: 'I'm here because of Ashley.' By itself, that single moment of recognition between that young white girl and that old black man is not enough. It is not enough to give healthcare to the sick, or jobs to the jobless, or education to our children.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Obama honestly acknowledges that a single moment of recognition is not sufficient to solve healthcare, joblessness, or education — the problems remain real and structural.

paragraphs.text: But it is where we start. It is where our union grows stronger. And as so many generations have come to realize over the course of the two hundred and twenty-one years since a band of patriots signed that document in Philadelphia, that is where the perfection begins.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: But that moment of recognition is where the union begins to grow stronger — the starting point of the 'more perfect union' that each generation is called to continue building.

title: The Great Society
speaker: Lyndon B. Johnson
summary: Johnson contrasts abundance and current problems with a vision of a transformed Great Society.
introduction: Lyndon B. Johnson delivered this commencement address at the University of Michigan in May 1964, at a pivotal moment in his presidency. The Vietnam War was escalating, civil rights legislation was advancing through Congress, and Johnson envisioned an ambitious domestic agenda. Addressing university graduates and, by extension, the nation, Johnson articulated a comprehensive vision for American society beyond poverty, material consumption, and racial injustice. The occasion allowed him to frame social reform as aligned with young Americans' idealistic impulses, crucial as anti-war sentiment was beginning to mobilize on campuses. Johnson spoke before an educated, future-leading audience, seeking to inspire their participation in social transformation and to establish the moral legitimacy of his expansive social programs. The speech launched the political branding of the 'Great Society,' which would define his presidency and reshape American government's role in addressing social problems.

paragraphs.text: For a century we laboured to settle and to subdue a continent. For half a century we called upon unbounded invention and untiring industry to create an order of plenty for all of our people. The challenge of the next half century is whether we have the wisdom to use that wealth to enrich and elevate our national life, and to advance the quality of our American civilization.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Sets baseline of past achievement and poses central question about using wealth for civilization advancement.

paragraphs.text: Your imagination, your initiative, and your indignation will determine whether we build a society where progress is the servant of our needs, or a society where old values and new visions are buried under unbridled growth. For in your time we have the opportunity to move not only towards the rich society and the powerful society, but upward to the Great Society.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Rejects unbridled growth that buries old values and new visions; implicitly criticizes materialism.

paragraphs.text: The Great Society rests on abundance and liberty for all. It demands an end to poverty and racial injustice, to which we are totally committed in our time. But that is just the beginning.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Identifies existing injustices (poverty and racial inequality) that must be addressed as foundation for Great Society.

paragraphs.text: The Great Society is a place where every child can find knowledge to enrich his mind and to enlarge his talents. It is a place where leisure is a welcome chance to build and reflect, not a feared cause of boredom and restlessness. It is a place where the city of man serves not only the needs of the body and the demands of commerce but the desire for beauty and the hunger for community.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Begins detailed portrait of Great Society emphasizing enriched minds, meaningful leisure, and community over commerce.

paragraphs.text: It is a place where man can renew contact with nature. It is a place which honours creation for its own sake and for what it adds to the understanding of the race. It is a place where men are more concerned with the quality of their goals than the quantity of their goods.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Continues vision with connection to nature, creation, and values of quality over quantity.

paragraphs.text: But most of all, the Great Society is not a safe harbour, a resting place, a final objective, a finished work. It is a challenge constantly renewed, beckoning us towards a destiny where the meaning of our lives matches the marvellous products of our labour ...
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Reframes Great Society as an ongoing challenge and aspiration rather than final destination.

paragraphs.text: Our society will never be great until our cities are great. Today the frontier of imagination and innovation is inside those cities and not beyond their borders.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Identifies cities as critical problem area where innovation and imagination must be directed.

paragraphs.text: New experiments are already going on. It will be the task of your generation to make the American city a place where future generations will come, not only to live but to live the good life ...
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Directly assigns the task of city transformation to the young audience's generation.

paragraphs.text: A second place where we begin to build the Great Society is in our countryside. We have always prided ourselves on being not only America the strong and America the free, but America the beautiful. Today that beauty is in danger. The water we drink, the food we eat, the very air that we breathe, are threatened with pollution. Our parks are overcrowded, our seashores overburdened. Green fields and dense forests are disappearing.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Describes environmental degradation threatening the nation's beauty and natural resources.

paragraphs.text: A few years ago we were greatly concerned about the 'Ugly American'. Today we must act to prevent an ugly America.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Rejects the failed identity of 'Ugly American' and implicitly its materialist values.

paragraphs.text: For once the battle is lost, once our natural splendour is destroyed, it can never be recaptured. And once man can no longer walk with beauty or wonder at nature his spirit will wither and his sustenance be wasted.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Emphasizes the irreversible consequences of environmental destruction and spiritual decline.

paragraphs.text: A third place to build the Great Society is in the classrooms of America. There your children's lives will be shaped. Our society will not be great until every young mind is set free to scan the farthest reaches of thought and imagination. We are still far from that goal.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Identifies inadequate education and classroom conditions as a major problem area.

paragraphs.text: Today, eight million adult Americans, more than the entire population of Michigan, have not finished five years of school. Nearly twenty million have not finished eight years of school. Nearly fifty-four million -- more than one-quarter of all America -- have not even finished high school ...
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Provides stark statistics demonstrating the scale and scope of educational deficiency in America.

paragraphs.text: In many places, classrooms are overcrowded and curricula are outdated. Most of our qualified teachers are underpaid, and many of our paid teachers are unqualified. So we must give every child a place to sit and a teacher to learn from. Poverty must not be a bar to learning, and learning must offer an escape from poverty ...
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Details specific failures: overcrowding, outdated curricula, underpaid qualified teachers, unqualified paid teachers.

paragraphs.text: There are those timid souls who say this battle cannot be won; that we are condemned to a soulless wealth. I do not agree. We have the power to shape the civilization that we want. But we need your will, your labour, your hearts, if we are to build that kind of society.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Explicitly rejects the false claim that the battle is unwinnable and that we are condemned to soulless wealth.

paragraphs.text: Those who came to this land sought to build more than just a new country. They sought a new world. So I have come here today to your campus to say that you can make their vision our reality. So let us from this moment begin our work so that in the future men will look back and say: It was then, after a long and weary way, that man turned the exploits of his genius to the full enrichment of his life.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Direct appeal to young audience to transform the vision of earlier generations into reality through immediate action.

title: My country today stands at the start of a journey
speaker: Aung San Suu Kyi
summary: Suu Kyi contrasts Burma's authoritarian past with democratic future and calls for international support.
introduction: Aung San Suu Kyi delivered this address on June 21, 2012, before the joint Houses of Commons and Lords in Westminster Hall, London, her first visit overseas in years after decades of house arrest and political persecution under Burma's military junta. She had recently been elected as a Member of Parliament in Burma's April 2012 by-elections, a limited but historic opening in a country still under significant military influence. Speaking to the British Parliament, the institutional model for Burma's own parliamentary system, Suu Kyi appealed for continued British and Western engagement as Burma undertook a fragile democratic transition. Her audience included legislators who had championed her cause during years of imprisonment and a global public watching whether Burma's opening was genuine. The occasion required her to balance gratitude toward Western supporters with frank assessment of how much work remained, while making the case that Burma's democratic experiment deserved sustained international investment rather than complacent celebration.

paragraphs.text: In June 2012, Aung San Suu Kyi visited the UK and four other European countries during her first visit overseas in many years. She had been leader of Burma's National League for Democracy almost continuously since 1988, but only recently elected as an MP. On 21 June, she addressed the joint Houses of Commons and Lords in Westminster Hall, giving this impassioned plea for Britain to assist her country as it struggled to recreate itself as a parliamentary democracy.
paragraphs.comment: Context and introduction to the speech occasion.

paragraphs.text: At the heart of her speech is a comparison between the hard-won, fledgling democracy of Burma and the British parliamentary system on which it was modelled, 'perhaps the pre-eminent symbol to oppressed peoples around the world of freedom of speech'. In her appeal for support and assistance, she warns against complacency, suggesting that many in the West take their democracy for granted.
paragraphs.comment: Framing the comparison between Burma and British parliamentary tradition.

paragraphs.text: A calm but undemonstrative speaker, she referred closely to her notes throughout the speech, and made few hand gestures - though the solemnity of her speech is leavened with anecdotes and gentle humour. More than charisma and panache, she relies on two factors: the simple, common-sense imperatives embedded in the content of her speech, and the personal authority accorded to her by much of the world.
paragraphs.comment: Description of Suu Kyi's speaking style and rhetorical approach.

paragraphs.text: Lord Speaker, Mr Speaker, Mr Prime Minister, 1  My Lords and Members of the House of Commons. Thank you for inviting me to speak to you here in this magnificent hall. I am very conscious of the extraordinary nature of this honour…
paragraphs.comment: Formal address and thanks to Parliament.

paragraphs.text: I have just come from Downing Street. 2  It was my first visit there, and yet for me it was a familiar scene - not just from television broadcasts, but from my own family history. As some of you may be aware, the best-known photograph of my father, Aung San, taken shortly before his assassination in 1947, was of him standing in Downing Street with Clement Attlee 3  and others, with whom he had been discussing Burma's transition to independence…
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Personal connection to Downing Street establishes continuity from her father's independence negotiations to present moment.

paragraphs.text: A couple of hours ago I was photographed in the same place where my father was photographed, together with Prime Minister David Cameron, and it was raining. Very British! My father was a founding member of the Burmese Independence Army 4  in World War II. He took on this responsibility out of a desire to see democracy established in his homeland. It was his view that democracy was the only political system worthy of an independent nation. It is a view of course that I have long shared.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Her father's commitment to democracy and her inherited mission frame Burma's current struggle as continuation of historical independence fight.

paragraphs.text: General Slim, 5  commander of the 14th Army, who led the Allied Burmese campaign, wrote about his first encounter with my father in his memoir Defeat until Victory. The meeting came towards the end of the war, shortly after my father had decided that the Burmese Independence Army should join forces with the Allies. General Slim said to my father: 'You've only come to us because we are winning.' To which my father replied, 'It wouldn't be much good coming to you if you weren't!' Slim saw in my father a practical man with whom he could do business. Six decades later, I strive to be as practical as my father was.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Anecdote about General Slim and her father illustrates practical, pragmatic approach to achieving democratic goals despite adversity.

paragraphs.text: And so I am here, in part, to ask for practical help. Help as a friend and as an equal. In support of the reforms which can bring better lives and greater opportunities to the people of Burma who have been for so long deprived of their rights and place in the world.
paragraphs.comment: Transition to purpose of visit and request for support.

paragraphs.text: As I said yesterday in Oxford, 6  my country today stands at the start of a journey toward I hope a better future. So many hills remain to be climbed, chasms to be bridged, obstacles to be breached.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Core metaphor of journey beginning establishes starting point: Burma at crossroads, not at destination.

paragraphs.text: Our own determination can get us so far. The support of the people of Britain and of peoples around the world can get us so much further.
paragraphs.comment: Acknowledges internal effort and need for external support to succeed.

paragraphs.text: In a speech about change and reform, it is very appropriate to be in Westminster Hall, because at the heart of this process must be the establishment of a strong, parliamentary institution in my own country. The British Parliament is perhaps the pre-eminent symbol to oppressed peoples around the world of freedom of speech. I would imagine that some people here, to some extent, take this freedom for granted.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Britain's Parliament as symbol of freedom shows what Burma seeks; warns against Western complacency about democracy.

paragraphs.text: For us in Burma, what you take for granted, we have had to struggle for long and hard. So many people in Burma gave up so much, gave up everything, in Burma's ongoing struggle for democracy, and we are only now just beginning to see the fruits of our struggle.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Contrasts Burma's hard-won struggles for democracy with Western assumption of freedom.

paragraphs.text: Westminster has long set a shining example of realizing the people's desire to be part of their own legislative process. In Burma our parliament is in its infancy, having been established only in March 2011. As with any new institution, especially an institution which goes against the cultural grain of 49 years of direct military rule, it will take time to find its feet and time to find its voice.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Parliament's infancy and challenge of overcoming 49 years of military rule establishes difficulty and magnitude of transition.

paragraphs.text: Our new legislative processes, which undoubtedly are an improvement on what has gone before, are not as transparent as they might be. I would like to see us learn from established examples of parliamentary democracies elsewhere, so that we might deepen our own democratic standards over time.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Current legislative processes need transparency and learning from established democracies.

paragraphs.text: Earlier this year I myself participated in my first election as a candidate. To this day, however, I have not yet had the chance to vote freely in any election. In 1990 I was allowed to cast an advance vote while under house arrest.
paragraphs.comment: Transition: heading highlighting electoral participation as critical foundation.

paragraphs.text: But I was prevented from contesting as a candidate for my party, the National League for Democracy. I was disqualified on the grounds that I had received help from foreign quarters. This amounted to BBC broadcasts that the authorities considered to be biased in my favour. What struck me most, ahead of this year's by-elections, was how quickly people in the constituencies around Burma grasped the importance of participating in the political process. They understood first hand that the right to vote was not something given to all. They understood that they must take advantage when the opportunity arose, because they understood what it meant to have that opportunity taken away from them…
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Personal narrative of participating in first election while never having voted freely; illustrates constraints still operating.

paragraphs.text: It has been less than 100 days, since I, together with my fellow National League for Democracy candidates, was out on the campaign trail across Burma. Our byelections were held on April 1st, and I was conscious there was a certain scepticism that this would turn out to be an elaborate April Fool's joke. In fact, it turned out to be an April of new hope.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Disqualification and arbitrary authority highlight ongoing repression; people's understanding of voting's value shows resilience despite constraints.

paragraphs.text: The voting process was largely free and fair, and I would like to pay tribute to President Thein 7  for this and for his commitment and his sincerity in the reform process.
paragraphs.comment: Transition between describing past constraints and recent hopeful election results.

paragraphs.text: As I have long said, it is through dialogue and through cooperation that political differences can best be resolved, and my own commitment to this path remains as strong as ever.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: April Fool's Fool's joke reference subtly acknowledges skepticism that the reform is genuine; 'April of new hope' counters the false promise of instant transformation.

paragraphs.text: Elections in Burma are very different to those in many more established democracies such as yours. Apathy, especially among the young, is certainly not an issue. For me, the most encouraging and rewarding aspect of our own elections was the participation, in such vast numbers and with such enthusiasm, of our young people. Often, our biggest challenge was in restraining the crowds of university students, schoolchildren and flag-waving toddlers who greeted us on the campaign, blocking the roads throughout the length of towns…
paragraphs.comment: Tribute to President Thein Sein for electoral fairness; acknowledgment of positive beginning.

paragraphs.text: The passion of the electorate was a passion born of hunger for something long denied.
paragraphs.comment: Commitment to dialogue and cooperation as pathway for resolving differences.

paragraphs.text: Following Burma's independence in 1948, our parliamentary system was of course based on that of the United Kingdom. The era became known in Burmese as the Parliamentary Era, a name which, by the mere necessity of its application, speaks of the unfortunate changes which followed.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Youth participation embodies hope and enthusiasm for democratic participation despite previous repression.

paragraphs.text: Our parliamentary era, which lasted more or less until 1962, could not be said to have been perfect. But it was certainly the most progressive and promising period until now in the short history of independent Burma. It was at this time that Burma was considered the nation most likely to succeed in South-East Asia. Things did not, however, go entirely to plan. They often don't in Burma and indeed in the rest of the world.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Passion of electorate represents hunger for democracy long denied; shows positive energy driving change.

paragraphs.text: Now, once again, we have an opportunity to re-establish true democracy in Burma. It is an opportunity for which we have waited many decades. If we do not use this opportunity, if we do not get things right this time around, it may be several decades more before a similar opportunity arises again.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Historical parliamentary era (1948-1962) as most progressive period establishes precedent and possibility.

paragraphs.text: And so it is for this reason that I would ask Britain, as one of the oldest parliamentary democracies, to consider what it can do to build the sound institutions needed to support our nascent parliamentary democracy.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Failure of that era due to external factors and loss of opportunity frames current transition as crucial window.

paragraphs.text: The reforms taking place, led by President Thein Sein, are to be welcomed. But this cannot be a personality-based process. Without strong institutions, this process will not be sustainable. Our legislature has much to learn about the democratization process, and I hope that Britain and other democracies can help by sharing your own experiences with us…
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Warning that missing this opportunity could mean decades before another chance; implicitly rejects false promise that one election solves everything.

paragraphs.text: …What is most important is to empower the people, the essential ingredient of democracy. Britain is living proof that a constitution does not need to be written down to be effective. It is more important that a constitution should be accepted by the people, that the people should feel it belongs to them, that it is not an external document imposed on them.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Direct appeal to Britain to help build sound institutions; action requires institutional development, not just electoral victory.

paragraphs.text: One of the clearly stated aims of my party, the National League for Democracy, is constitutional reform. Britain's  original constitution was drawn up following 8 the meeting between my father Aung San and Clement Attlee here in London in 1947. This constitution may not have been perfect, but at its core was a profound understanding of and respect for the aspirations of the people.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Reforms welcomed but cannot be personality-based; need sustainable institutions and learning from established democracies.

paragraphs.text: The current constitution, drawn up by the military government in 2008, must be amended to incorporate the basic rights and aspirations of Burma's ethnic nationalities. In over 60 years of independence, Burma has not yet known a time when we could say that there is peace throughout the land…
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Empowering the people as essential ingredient of democracy; constitution must belong to people, not be imposed.

paragraphs.text: We need to address the problems that lie at the root of conflict. We need to develop a culture of political settlement through negotiation and to promote the rule of law, that all who live in Burma may enjoy the benefits of both freedom and security.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Party's constitutional reform aims reflect respect for people's aspirations; historical continuity with father's 1947 constitutional understanding.

paragraphs.text: In the immediate term, we also need humanitarian support for the many peoples in the north and west, largely women and children, who have been forced to flee their homes.
paragraphs.label: Current Reality
paragraphs.comment: Current military-drawn constitution must be amended; 60 years without peace indicates ongoing conflict rooted in constitutional failures.

paragraphs.text: And that is why I hope that in working for Burma's national reconciliation, the international community will recognize that it is political dialogue and political settlement which must be given precedence over short-term economic development.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Need to address root causes of conflict and develop culture of political settlement through negotiation.

paragraphs.text: If differences remain unresolved, if basic aspirations remain unfulfilled, there cannot be an adequate foundation for sustainable development of any kind economic, social or political.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Humanitarian support needed for displaced peoples in immediate term; urgent action required.

paragraphs.text: Britain has for so long, under successive governments - including the present Conservative / Liberal Democratic coalition, and the previous Labour government - been a staunch and unshakeable supporter of aid efforts in Burma. I hope that you can continue to help our country through targeted and coordinated development assistance.
paragraphs.comment: Transition heading about importance of preserving ethnic identity beyond economic development.

paragraphs.text: Britain has been until now the largest bilateral donor to Burma. It is in education in particular that I hope the British can play a major role…
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Political dialogue and settlement must precede economic development; international community must prioritize political reconciliation.

paragraphs.text: Vocational training and creation of employment opportunities to help address
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Unresolved differences prevent adequate foundation for sustainable development; interconnection of political and economic progress.

paragraphs.text: Burma's chronic youth unemployment are particularly important. Longer term, Burma's education system is desperately weak. Reform is needed, not just of schools and the curriculum and the training of teachers, but also of our attitude to education, which at present is too narrow and rigid.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Britain's long support acknowledged; appeal for continued targeted development assistance from established allies.

paragraphs.text: I hope also that British businesses can play a role in supporting the democratic reform process, through what I have termed democracy-friendly investment. By this I mean investment that prioritizes transparency, accountability, workers' rights and environmental sustainability. Investment particularly in labourintensive sectors, when carried out responsibly and with positive intent, can offer real benefits to our people.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Britain as largest bilateral donor should focus on education; recognition and appeal for sustained involvement.

paragraphs.text: One test will be whether new players will benefit from the investment coming in. Britain has played an important role in facilitating the forthcoming visit, next month, of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative Secretariat. 9  I hope this will be the start of many similar initiatives in the months ahead.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Vocational training and employment for youth unemployment; education system reform needed across schools, curriculum, teaching, and attitude.

paragraphs.text: It was through learning, while at Oxford, about two great British leaders, Gladstone 10  and Disraeli, 11 that I first developed my understanding of parliamentary democracy. I learnt the basics: that one accepts the decision of the voters; that the governing power is gained and relinquished in accordance with the desires of the electorate, that it is a system which goes on, and that ultimately everyone gets another chance.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: British businesses can support through democracy-friendly investment emphasizing transparency, accountability, workers' rights, and sustainability.

paragraphs.text: These are things taken for granted here in Britain, but in 1990 in Burma, the winner of the elections was never allowed even to convene parliament. I hope that we can leave such days behind us, and that as we look forward to the future, it will be the will of the people that is reflected faithfully in Burma's changing political landscape.
paragraphs.label: Bridge to Action
paragraphs.comment: Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative as model for accountability; hope for similar initiatives in months ahead.

paragraphs.text: This journey out of Burma has not been a sentimental pilgrimage to the past, but an exploration of the new opportunities at hand for the people of Burma. I have been struck throughout my trip by how extraordinarily warm-hearted and open the world has been to us.
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Learning about Gladstone and Disraeli at Oxford shaped understanding of parliamentary democracy; system where power transfers with voter will.

paragraphs.text: To experience this first-hand, after so long physically separated from the world, has been very moving.
paragraphs.label: Opposition's False Promise
paragraphs.comment: Contrast between Britain where election winners govern and 1990 Burma where they were prevented from even convening parliament; rejects false promise of electoral legitimacy.

paragraphs.text: Countries that geographically are distant have shown that they are close to Burma in what really matters: they are close to the aspirations of the people of Burma…
paragraphs.label: Vision of Hope
paragraphs.comment: Journey is exploration of new opportunities, not sentimental return to past; forward-looking hopeful tone.

paragraphs.text: During the years of my house arrest, it was not just the BBC and other broadcasting stations that kept me in touch with the world outside.
