paragraphs.comment: Darrow attributes the post-war increase in homicide rates to society's normalization of killing during wartime, not to inadequate punishment.

paragraphs.text: We teach people to kill, and the state is the one that teaches them. If a state wishes that its citizens respect human life, then the state should stop killing. It can be done in no other way, and it will perhaps not be fully done that way. There are infinite reasons for killing. There are infinite circumstances under which there are more or less deaths. It never did depend and never can depend upon the severity of the punishment.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that state-sanctioned killing teaches citizens to devalue life, and that the state must stop killing if it wants citizens to respect life.

paragraphs.text: He talks about the United States being a lawless country. Well, the people somehow prefer it. There is such a thing as a people being too servile to law. You may take China with her caste system and much of Europe, which has much more caste than we. It may be full of homicides, but there is less bread and there is less fun; there is less opportunity for the poor. In any new country, homicide is more frequent than in an old country, because there is a higher degree of equality. It is always true wherever you go. And in the older countries, as a general rule, there are fewer homicides because nobody ever thinks of getting out of his class; nobody ever dreams of such a thing.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that homicide rates are higher in societies with greater equality and opportunity, not simply because of lenient punishment.

paragraphs.text: But let's see what there is in this argument. He says, "Everybody who kills, dreads hanging." Well, he has had experiences as a lawyer on both sides. I have had experience on one side. I know that everybody who is taken into court on a murder charge desires to live, and they do not want to be hanged or electrocuted. Even a thing as alluring as being cooked with electricity doesn't appeal to them.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow directly addresses the opponent's claim that convicted killers dread hanging, distinguishing between the mental state at the time of crime versus at trial.

paragraphs.text: But that hasn't anything to do with it. What was the state of mind when the homicide was committed? The state of mind is one thing when a homicide is committed and another thing weeks or months afterward, when every reason for committing it is gone. There is no comparison between it. There never can be any comparison between it.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues the fear of punishment at trial is irrelevant because the mental state during the killing is entirely different, undermining the deterrence rationale.

paragraphs.text: We might ask why people kill. I don't want to dispute with him about the right of the state to kill people. Of course, they have got a right to kill them. That is about all we do. The great industry of the world for four long years was killing. They have got a right to kill, of course. That is, they have got the power. And you have got a right to do what you get away with. The words "power" and "right," so far as this is concerned, mean exactly the same thing. So nobody who has any knowledge of philosophy would pretend to say that the state had not the right to kill.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow dismisses the moral authority of the state to kill by noting that killing is what states do, and power is not the same as right.

paragraphs.text: But why not do a good job of it? If you want to get rid of killings by hanging people or electrocuting them because these are so terrible, why not make a punishment that is terrible? This isn't so much. It lasts but a short time. There is no physical torture in it. Why not boil them in oil, as they used to do? Why not burn them at the stake? Why not sew them into a bag with serpents and throw them out to sea? Why not take them out on the sand and let them be eaten by ants? Why not break every bone in their body on the rack, as has been done for such serious offenses as heresy and witchcraft?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Using Swift-like satirical escalation, Darrow argues that if severity of punishment deters, logic demands returning to far more brutal historical penalties.

paragraphs.text: Those were the good old days in which the judge should have held court. Glorious days, when you could kill them by the million because they worshiped God in a different way from that which the state provided, or when you could kill old women for witchcraft! There might be some sense in it if you could kill young ones, but not old ones. Those were the glorious days of capital punishment. And there wasn't a judge or a preacher who didn't think that the life of the state depended upon their right to hang old women for witchcraft and to persecute others for worshiping God in the wrong way.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow extends his satire by invoking the 'glorious days' of mass executions for heresy and witchcraft, exposing the historical absurdity of capital punishment as deterrent.

paragraphs.text: Why, our capital punishment isn't worth talking about, so far as its being a preventive is concerned. It isn't worth discussing. Why not call back from the dead and barbarous past the hundred and sixty or seventy-odd crimes that were punishable by death in England? Why not once more reenact the blue laws of our own country and kill people right? Why not resort to all the tortures that the world has always resorted to to keep men in the straight and narrow path? Why reduce it to a paltry question of murder?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow pushes the reductio ad absurdum further, questioning why we have reduced the list of capital crimes if punishment severity truly prevents crime.

paragraphs.text: Everybody in this world has some pet aversion to something, and on account of that pet aversion they would like to hang somebody. If the prohibitionists made the law, they would be in favor of hanging you for taking a drink, or certainly for bootlegging, because to them that is the most heinous crime there is.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow illustrates how arbitrary and personal the definition of capital crime is by noting that prohibitionists would hang people for drinking.

paragraphs.text: Some men slay or murder. Why? As a matter of fact, murder as murder is very rare; and the people, who commit it, as a rule, are of a much higher type than others. You may go to any penitentiary and, as a rule, those who have been convicted of murder become the trusties; whereas, if you are punishing somebody as a sneak thief or a counterfeiter or a confidence man, they never get over it---never.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow observes that murderers are often among the most trustworthy prison inmates, while petty criminals remain incorrigible, challenging assumptions about who deserves death.

paragraphs.text: Now, I don't know how injustice is administered in New York. I just know about Chicago. But I am glad to learn from the gentleman that if a man is so poor in New York that he can't hire a lawyer, that he has a first-class lawyer appointed to defend him---a first-class lawyer appointed to defend him. Don't take a chance and go out and kill anybody on the statement made by my friend.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow sarcastically challenges his opponent's claim that poor defendants receive quality legal representation, drawing on his Chicago courtroom experience.

paragraphs.text: I suppose anybody can go out and kill somebody and ask to have my friend Sam Untermyer appointed. There never was such a thing. Here and there, a good lawyer may have defended people for nothing. But no court ever interferes with a good lawyer's business by calling him in and compelling him to give his time. They have been lawyers too recently themselves to ever work a trick like that on a lawyer. As a rule, it is the poor and the weak and the friendless who furnish the victims of the law.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow asserts that it is 'the poor and the weak and the friendless' who are executed, providing evidence of systemic inequality in capital punishment's application.

paragraphs.text: Let me take another statement of my friend. He said, "Oh, we don't hang anybody if they kill when they are angry; it is only when they act premeditatedly." Yes, I have been in courts and heard judges instruct people on this premeditated act. It is only when they act under their judgment and with due consideration. He would also say that if a man is moved by anger, but if he doesn't strike the deadly blow until such time as reason and judgment has a chance to possess him, even if it is a second---how many times have I heard judges say, "Even if it is a second?" What does any judge know about premeditation? What does anybody know about it? How many people are there in this world that can premeditate on anything? I will strike out the "pre" and say how many people are there that can meditate?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow challenges the legal concept of premeditation as psychologically meaningless, questioning whether any judge or person truly understands it.

paragraphs.text: How long does it take the angry man for his passions to cool when he is in the presence of the thing that angers him? There never was a premeditated murder in any sense of psychology or of science. There are planned murders---planned, yes---but back of every murder and back of every human act are sufficient causes that move the human machine beyond their control.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that premeditation as a legal category is scientifically invalid because human actions are always driven by prior causes beyond individual control.

paragraphs.text: The other view is an outworn, outlawed, unscientific theory of the metaphysicians. Does anybody ever act in this world without a motive? Did they ever act without a sufficient motive? And who am I to say that John Smith premeditated? I might premeditate a good deal quicker than John Smith did. My judgment might have a chance to act quicker than John Smith's judgment had a chance to act.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow extends his determinism argument, asserting that free will-based notions of premeditation are unscientific metaphysical fictions.

paragraphs.text: We have heard talk of justice. Is there anybody who knows what justice is? No one on earth can measure out justice. Can you look at any man and say what he deserves---whether he deserves hanging by the neck until dead or life in prison or thirty days in prison or a medal? The human mind is blind to all who seek to look in at it and to most of us that look out from it. Justice is something that man knows little about. He may know something about charity and understanding and mercy, and he should cling to these as far as he can.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that justice is unknowable and that mercy, charity, and understanding are the only guideposts humans can reliably follow.

paragraphs.text: Now, let me see if I am right about my statement that no man believes in hanging, except for a kick or revenge. How about my friend Judge Talley, here. He criticizes the state of New York because a prisoner may be shown moving pictures. What do you think about it---those of you who think? What do you feel about it---those of you who have passed the hyena age? I know what they think. What do you think about shutting up a man in a penitentiary for twenty years, in a cell four feet wide and seven feet long---twenty years, mind!---and complaining because he had a chance now and then to go out and see a moving picture---go out of his cell?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow challenges Judge Talley's criticism of prison amenities, arguing that objecting to humane prison conditions reveals a desire for revenge, not justice.

paragraphs.text: A body of people who feels that way could never get rid of capital punishment. If you really felt it, you would feel like the Indian who used the tomahawk on his enemy and who burned him and embalmed his face with the ashes.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that people who want harsher prison conditions would never be able to abolish capital punishment, exposing the retributive mindset.

paragraphs.text: But what is punishment about anyway? I put a man in prison for the purpose of getting rid of him and for such example as there might be. Is it up to you to torture him while he is there? Supposing you provided that every man who went to prison should be compelled to wear a nail half an inch long in his shoe. I suppose some of you would do it. I don't know whether the judge would or not, from what he said.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow questions the purpose of punishment, arguing there is no justification for torturing prisoners beyond their imprisonment.

paragraphs.text: Is there any reason for torturing someone who happens to be in prison? Is there any reason why an actor or even an actress might not go there and sing? There is no objection to a preacher going there. Why not give him a little pleasure?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow continues challenging the rationale for additional prison suffering, using rhetorical questions to expose the cruelty of punitive thinking.

paragraphs.text: And they really get food there---what do you know about that? Now, when I heard him tell about what wonderful food they get---dietary food---did you ever know anybody that liked dietary food? I suppose the constitution of the state of New York contains the ordinary provision against cruel and inhuman punishment, and yet you send them up there and feed them on dietary food.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow uses sarcasm about 'dietary food' in prison to mock the idea that prison conditions are too comfortable, highlighting the cruelty of the opposing view.

paragraphs.text: And you can take your meals out! Now, some of you might not have noticed that I walked over and asked the warden about it. The reason I did that is because I am stopping over here at the Belmont, and I didn't know but I'd rather go up and board with him.
paragraphs.comment: Darrow inserts a humorous personal anecdote about considering prison dining as an alternative to his hotel, using levity to deflate his opponent's complaints.

paragraphs.text: Now, this is what I find out: that those who have gained consideration by good conduct over a considerable period---one year---they may spend three dollars a week for board. I pay more than that over here. They ought to pass some law in New York to prevent the inmates getting dyspepsia. And for those who attain the second class, they may spend a dollar and a half a week. And for those below the second class, nothing can come from outside---nothing. A pure matter of prison discipline!
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow provides specific details about prison dining privileges to show how modest the actual conditions are, undercutting claims of excessive prisoner comfort.

paragraphs.text: Why, I wonder if the judge ever took pains to go up there. I will tell you. I have had some experience with people that know them pretty well. I never saw a man who wanted to go to prison, even to see the movies. I never saw a man in my life who didn't want to get out.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow draws on his direct experience with incarcerated people to assert that no one wants to be in prison, regardless of any small amenities.

paragraphs.text: I wonder what you would have. Of course, I live in Chicago, where people are fairly human---I don't know, maybe I don't understand the New York people. What would you have? Suppose you could tell yourselves how a person was to be treated while in prison---and it doesn't require a great amount of imagination. Most people can think of some relative or some friends who are there. If you can't, most of you can think of a good many that ought to be there. How would you have them treated---something worse than being shut up in a cell, four by seven, and given light work---like being a judge or practicing law---something worse than dietary food?
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow asks the audience to imagine a friend or relative in prison and how they would want them treated, using empathy to counter the punitive worldview.

paragraphs.text: I will tell you. There is just one thing in all this question. It is a question of how you feel, that is all. It is all inside of you. If you love the thought of somebody being killed, why, you are for it. If you hate the thought of somebody being killed, you are against it.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow returns to his core thesis: opposition to capital punishment is entirely a matter of one's emotional relationship to the act of killing.

paragraphs.text: Let me just take a little brief review of what has happened in this world. They used to hang people on the crossways and on a high hill, so that everybody would be awed into goodness by the sight. They have tortured them in every way that the brain of man could conceive. They have provided every torture known or that could be imagined for one who believed differently from his fellowman---and still the belief persisted. They have maimed and scarred and starved and killed human beings since man began penning his fellowman. Why? Because we hate him. And what has added to it is that they have done it under the false ideal of self-righteousness.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow surveys the history of brutal punishment across civilizations, arguing that cruelty has always been driven by hatred masquerading as righteousness.

paragraphs.text: I have heard parents punish their children and tell their children it hurt the parent more than it did the child. I don't believe it. I have tried it both ways, and I don't believe it. I know better.
paragraphs.comment: Darrow uses a wry personal observation about parental punishment to deflate the self-righteous claim that punishment hurts the punisher more than the punished.

paragraphs.text: Gradually, the world has been lopping off these punishments. Why? Because we have grown a little more sensitive, a little more imaginative, a little kindlier, that is all.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow traces humanity's gradual elimination of brutal punishments to growing sensitivity and imagination, framing abolition as moral progress.

paragraphs.text: Why not reenact the code of Blackstone's day? Why, the judges were all for it---every one of them---and the only way we got rid of those laws was because juries were too humane to obey the courts.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow cites historical evidence that capital laws were eliminated not by courts but by juries too humane to enforce them, showing how popular sentiment leads reform.

paragraphs.text: That is the only way we got rid of punishing old women, of hanging old women in New England---because, in spite of all the courts, the juries would no longer convict them for a crime that never existed. And in that way they have cut down the crimes in England for punishment by death from one hundred and seventy to two. What is going to happen if we get rid of them? Is the world coming to an end? The earth has been here ages and ages before man came. It will be here ages and ages after he disappears, and the amount of people you hang won't make the slightest difference with it.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow continues tracing the historical reduction of capital offenses in England from 170 to 2, arguing this trend will continue until abolition is complete.

paragraphs.text: Now, why am I opposed to capital punishment? It is too horrible a thing for a state to undertake. We are told by my friend, "Oh, the killer does it; why shouldn't the state?" I would hate to live in a state that I didn't think was better than a murderer.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow states directly that capital punishment is 'too horrible a thing for a state to undertake' and that the state should be morally superior to murderers.

paragraphs.text: But I told you the real reason. The people of the state kill a man because he killed someone else---that is all---without the slightest logic, without the slightest application to life, simply from anger, nothing else!
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that state killing is pure anger without logic, made in exact imitation of the murderer's act, not justice.

paragraphs.text: I am against it because I believe it is inhuman, because I believe that as the hearts of men have softened they have gradually gotten rid of brutal punishment, because I believe that it will only be a few years until it will be banished forever from every civilized country---even New York---because I believe that it has no effect whatever to stop murder.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow enumerates his reasons for opposing capital punishment: it is inhuman, historically regressive, soon to be abolished worldwide, and has no deterrent effect.

paragraphs.text: Now, let's make that simple and see. Where do the murders come from? I would say the second-largest class of what we call murders grows out of domestic relations. They follow those deep and profound feelings that are at the basis of life---and the feelings which give the greatest joy are susceptible of the greatest pain when they go ariot.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow identifies domestic passion as the second-largest source of murder, arguing these killings arise from deep emotional forces impervious to deterrence.

paragraphs.text: Can you imagine a woman following a man around with a pistol to kill him that would stop if you said, "Oh, you will be hanged!" Nothing doing---not if the world was coming to an end! Can you imagine a man doing it? Not at all. They think of it afterwards, but not before.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow uses the example of a crime of passion to show that no rational calculus about punishment enters a killer's mind in the moment, disproving deterrence.

paragraphs.text: They come from acts like burglary and robbery. A man goes out to rob or to burglarize. Somebody catches him or stops him or recognizes him, and he kills to save himself. Do you suppose there was ever a burglar or robber since the world began who would not kill to save himself? Is there anybody who wouldn't? It doesn't make any difference who. Wouldn't he take a chance shooting? Anyone would do it. Why, my friend himself said he would kill in self-defense. That is what they do. If you are going to stop them, you ought to hang them for robbery---which would be a good plan---and then, of course, if one started out to rob, he would kill the victim before he robbed him.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that killings during robbery are acts of self-preservation instinct, not rational choices that could be deterred by threat of execution.

paragraphs.text: There isn't, I submit, a single admissible argument in favor of capital punishment. Nature loves life. We believe that life should be protected and preserved. The thing that keeps one from killing is the emotion they have against it; and the greater the sanctity that the state pays to life, the greater the feeling of sanctity the individual has for life.
paragraphs.label: Clear Position Statement
paragraphs.comment: Darrow delivers his logical conclusion: there is no admissible argument for capital punishment, and the state's sanctity for life promotes individual respect for life.

paragraphs.text: There is nothing in the history of the world that ever cheapened human life like our great war; next to that, the indiscriminate killing of men by the states.
paragraphs.label: Evidence Presentation
paragraphs.comment: Darrow argues that war and state killing are the two greatest forces cheapening human life, linking capital punishment to broader devaluation of life.

paragraphs.text: My friend says a man must be proven guilty first. Does anybody know whether anybody is guilty? There is a great deal implied in that. For me to do something or for you to do something is one thing; for some other man to do something quite another. To know what one deserves, requires infinite study, which no one can give to it. No one can determine the condition of the brain that did the act. It is out of the question.
paragraphs.label: Opposition Rebuttal
paragraphs.comment: Darrow challenges the premise that guilt can ever be fully determined, arguing that the complexity of human psychology makes certainty of culpability impossible.

paragraphs.text: All people are products of two things, and two things only---their heredity and their environment. And they act in exact accord with the heredity which they took from all the past, and for which they are in no wise responsible, and the environment, which reaches out to the farthest limit of all life that can influence them. We all act from the same way. And it ought to teach us to be charitable and kindly and understanding of our fellowman.
paragraphs.label: Logical Conclusion
paragraphs.comment: Darrow concludes with a deterministic argument: all people are products of heredity and environment, so judging anyone worthy of death requires an impossible standard of knowledge.

title: The laws that men have made
speaker: Emmeline Pankhurst
summary: Pankhurst argues women need voting rights to protect their legal interests in marriage
introduction: Emmeline Pankhurst was the founder and leader of the Women's Social and Political Union, the most militant wing of the British suffrage movement, which she had co-founded in 1903 after growing frustrated with the NUWSS's parliamentary petitioning strategy. She delivered this speech in 1908 in the Portman Rooms during the Putney by-election, one of a series of lectures given under the umbrella title 'The Importance of the Vote.' She spoke to audiences of women and potential allies at a moment when suffrage activism was escalating from civil disobedience toward property destruction. Her strategy in this speech was methodical rather than militant: she catalogued specific British laws governing marriage, divorce, child custody, and women's property rights to demonstrate concretely why women needed the vote. The occasion demanded persuasion, not just inspiration: Pankhurst needed to show skeptical audiences that 'politics' directly determined the conditions of ordinary women's lives.

paragraphs.text: Formed in 1887 from 17 separate groups, the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies had campaigned persistently but unsuccessfully to gain the vote for women. A growing sense of frustration drove Emmeline and her daughter Christabel Pankhurst to form breakaway groups: the Women's Social and Political Union in 1903 and the more militant Women's Freedom League in 1907.
paragraphs.comment: Biographical context about the founding of suffrage organizations; does not engage the framework.

paragraphs.text: Tactics pursued by members of these organizations included heckling political speeches and provoking the police to arrest them for disturbing the peace. Their activities attracted the desired attention, though they were also delightedly lampooned by cartoonists and mainstream newspapers. In 1907, the law was changed to allow women ratepayers to vote in local elections but this did not satisfy Pankhurst.
paragraphs.comment: Historical context about activist tactics and partial legislative gains; establishes the problem but not yet moral ground.

paragraphs.text: In 1908, she gave a series of lectures under the umbrella title The Importance of the Vote . This one was given in the Portman Rooms during the Putney byelection of that year, which added urgency to its message. In her bald but patiently reasoned attack on the status quo, Pankhurst recites men's legislative shortcomings, condemning them for their failure to improve ordinary women's lives.
paragraphs.comment: Speech introduction and framing; announces the methodical, reasoned approach to come.

paragraphs.text: What I am going to say to you tonight is not new. It is what we have been saying at every street corner, at every by-election during the last 18 months. It is perfectly well known to many members of my audience, but they will not mind if I repeat, for the benefit of those who are here for the first time tonight, those arguments and illustrations with which many of us are so very familiar.
paragraphs.comment: Speaker acknowledges repetition of message; signals transition to substantive argument.

paragraphs.text: It is important for women that in any legislation that affects women equally with men, those who make the laws should be responsible to women, in order that they may be forced to consult women and learn women's views when they are contemplating the making or the altering of laws.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: The central principle: those affected by laws should have a voice in making them—a democratic value the audience already accepts.

paragraphs.text: Very little has been done by legislation for women for many years - for obvious reasons. More and more of the time of Members of Parliament is occupied by the claims which are made on behalf of the people who are organized in various ways in order to promote the interests of their industrial organizations or their political or social organizations. So the Member of Parliament, if he does dimly realize that women have needs, has no time to attend to them, no time to give to the consideration of those needs. His time is fully taken up by attending to the needs of the people who have sent him to Parliament.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Expands the principle by explaining why women specifically need representation: legislators ignore women's needs because they lack organized political power.

paragraphs.text: While a great deal has been done, and a great deal more has been talked about for the benefit of the workers who have votes, yet so far as women are concerned, legislation relating to them has been practically at a standstill. Yet it is not because women have no need, or because their need is not very urgent. There are many laws on the statute-book today which are admittedly out of date, and call for reformation; laws which inflict very grave injustices on women. I want to call the attention of women who are here tonight to a few acts on the statute-book which press very hardly and very injuriously on women.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Shifts tone by asserting that despite women's urgent needs, legislation for women 'has been practically at a standstill' and identifies specific unjust laws.

paragraphs.text: Men politicians are in the habit of talking to women as if there were no laws that affect women. 'The fact is,' they say, 'the home is the place for women. Their interests are the rearing and training of children. These are the things that interest women. Politics have nothing to do with these things, and therefore politics do not concern women.' Yet the laws decide how women are to live in marriage, how their children are to be trained and educated, and what the future of their children is to be. All that is decided by act of Parliament. Let us take a few of these laws, and see what there is to say about them from the women's point of view.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Refutes the false argument that politics do not concern women; shows laws directly determine marriage, child education, and family structure—all supposedly 'woman's domain.'

paragraphs.text: First of all, let us take the marriage laws. They are made by men for women. Let us consider whether they are equal, whether they are just, whether they are wise. What security of maintenance has the married woman? Many a married woman, having given up her economic independence in order to marry, how is she compensated for that loss? What security does she get in that marriage for which she gave up economic independence? Take the case of a woman who has been earning a good income. She is told that she ought to give up her employment when she becomes a wife and a mother. What does she get in return?
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Opens the catalog of legal injustices with marriage laws; establishes that women sacrifice economic independence without legal security or compensation.

paragraphs.text: All that a married man is obliged by law to do for his wife is to provide for her shelter of some kind, food of some kind and clothing of some kind. It is left to his good pleasure to decide what the shelter shall be, what the food shall be, what the clothing shall be. It is left to him to decide what money shall be spent on the home, and how it shall be spent; the wife has no voice legally in deciding any of these things. She has no legal claim upon any definite portion of his income. If he is a good man, a conscientious man, he does the right thing. If he is not, if he chooses almost to starve his wife, she has no remedy. What he thinks sufficient is what she has to be content with.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details the wife's legal powerlessness: husband controls shelter, food, clothing, household spending; wife has no remedy if starved or abused.

paragraphs.text: I quite agree, in all these illustrations, that the majority of men are considerably better than the law compels them to be…but since there are some bad men, some unjust men, don't you agree with me that the law ought to be altered so that those men could be dealt with?
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Appeals to the audience's sense that even if most men are better than law requires, bad men should not escape accountability—makes the case for legal reform.

paragraphs.text: Take what happens to the woman if her husband dies and leaves her a widow, sometimes with little children. If a man is so insensible to his duties as a husband and father when he makes his will, as to leave all his property away from his wife and children, the law allows him to do it. That will is a valid one. So you see that the married woman's position is not a secure one. It depends entirely on her getting a good ticket in the lottery. If she has a good husband, well and good: if she has a bad one, she has to suffer, and she has no remedy. That is her position as a wife, and it is far from satisfactory.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Demonstrates widow's vulnerability: a husband can legally disinherit his wife and children, leaving her dependent on luck rather than rights.

paragraphs.text: Now let us look at her position if she has been very unfortunate in marriage, so unfortunate as to get a bad husband, an immoral husband, a vicious husband, a husband unfit to be the father of little children. We turn to the divorce court.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Transitions to divorce law; signals further injustices are coming.

paragraphs.text: How is she to get rid of such a man? If a man has got married to a bad wife, and he wants to get rid of her, he has but to prove against her one act of infidelity. But if a woman who is married to a vicious husband wants to get rid of him, not one act nor a thousand acts of infidelity entitle her to a divorce. She must prove either bigamy, desertion or gross cruelty, in addition to immorality, before she can get rid of that man.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Core injustice on divorce: husband needs one act of infidelity to divorce; wife needs bigamy, desertion, or gross cruelty plus infidelity—a deliberate legal asymmetry.

paragraphs.text: Let us consider her position as a mother. We have repeated this so often at our meetings that I think the echo of what we have said must have reached many.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Transitions to mother's legal status; announces this topic has been repeated at meetings, signaling its importance.

paragraphs.text: By English law, no married woman exists as the mother of the child she brings into the world. In the eyes of the law she is not the parent of her child.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Stark assertion of the central legal injustice: 'no married woman exists as the mother of the child she brings into the world'—a moral flashpoint.

paragraphs.text: The child, according to our marriage laws, has only one parent who can decide the future of the child, who can decide where it shall live, how it shall live, how much shall be spent upon it, how it shall be educated and what religion it shall profess. That parent is the father.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details the father's exclusive legal authority over the child's residence, education, religious upbringing, and spending.

paragraphs.text: These are examples of some of the laws that men have made, laws that concern women. I ask you, if women had had the vote, should we have had such laws? If women had had the vote, as men have the vote, we should have had equal laws. We should have had equal laws for divorce, and the law would have said that as nature has given to children two parents, so the law should recognize that they have two parents.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Poses the question that invokes the moral ideal: if women had voted, would such unjust laws exist? Asserts they would have had equal laws instead.

paragraphs.text: I have spoken to you about the position of the married woman who does not exist legally as a parent, the parent of her own child. In marriage, children have one parent. Out of marriage children have also one parent. That parent is the mother - the unfortunate mother. She alone is responsible for the future of her child; she alone is punished if her child is neglected and suffers from neglect.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Highlights the perverse logic for unmarried mothers: legally responsible for the child, punished for neglect, while fathers bear no accountability.

paragraphs.text: But let me give you one illustration. I was in Herefordshire during the byelection. While I was there, an unmarried mother was brought before the bench of magistrates, charged with having neglected her illegitimate child. She was a domestic servant, and had put the child out to nurse. The magistrates - there were colonels and landowners on that bench - did not ask what wages the mother got; they did not ask who the father was or whether he contributed to the support of the child. They sent that woman to prison for three months for having neglected her child.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Concrete vivid case: Herefordshire servant sent to prison for child neglect while no one investigated the father—the speech's moral flashpoint.

paragraphs.text: I ask you women here tonight: if women had had some share in the making of laws, don't you think they would have found a way of making all fathers of such children equally responsible with the mothers for the welfare of those children?
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Again invokes the moral ideal through a question: would women legislators not have made fathers equally responsible with mothers?

paragraphs.text: It is well to remember that, in view of what we have been told of what is the value of women's influence. Woman's influence is only effective when men want to do the thing that her influence is supporting.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Refutes the claim that women's influence suffices; shows it only works when men already agree—reinforcing the need for women's legal power.

paragraphs.text: Now let us look a little to the future. If it ever was important for women to have the vote, it is ten times more important today, because you cannot take up a newspaper, you cannot go to a conference, you cannot even go to church, without hearing a great deal of talk about social reform and a demand for social legislation. Of course, it is obvious that that kind of legislation - and the Liberal government tell us that if they remain in office long enough we are going to have a great deal of it - is of vital importance to women.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Extends the argument to future social legislation on housing and declares it a moral question requiring women's voice.

paragraphs.text: If we have the right kind of social legislation it will be a very good thing for women and children. If we have the wrong kind of social legislation, we may have the worst kind of tyranny that women have ever known since the world began. We are hearing about legislation to decide what kind of homes people are to live in. That surely is a question for women. Surely every woman, when she seriously thinks about it, will wonder how men by themselves can have the audacity to think that they can say what homes ought to be without consulting women.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Warns of the stakes: without women's voice in legislation, women may face 'the worst kind of tyranny'; calls for women to demand inclusion in decisions about homes.

paragraphs.text: Then take education. Since 1870 men have been trying to find out how to educate children. 1 I think they have not yet realized that if they are ever to find out how to educate children, they will have to take women into their confidence, and try to learn from women some of those lessons that the long experience of ages has taught to them. One cannot wonder that whole sessions of Parliament should be wasted on education bills…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Applies the argument to education; asserts men have failed to educate children properly because they have not consulted women's experience.

paragraphs.text: The more one thinks about the importance of the vote for women, the more one realizes how vital it is. We are finding out new reasons for the vote, new needs for the vote every day in carrying on our agitation.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Reinforces the vital importance of the vote as the method to address injustices already catalogued.

paragraphs.text: I hope that there may be a few men and women here who will go away determined at least to give this question more consideration than they have in the past. They will see that we women, who are doing so much to get the vote, want it because we realize how much good we can do with it when we have got it. We do not want it in order to boast of how much we have got. We do not want it because we want to imitate men or to be like men. We want it because without it we cannot do that work which it is necessary and right and proper that every man and woman should be ready and willing to undertake in the interests of the community of which they form a part.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Final appeal: asks listeners to consider the question seriously; frames the vote as a moral duty to do necessary work for the community, not as ambition or imitation.

paragraphs.text: Vladiinir Ilich Lenin
paragraphs.comment: Biographical information about Lenin; unrelated to Pankhurst's speech and framework.

paragraphs.text: Shrewd, dynamic, pedantic and implacable, the Marxist political activist Vladimir Ilich Lenin (1870-1924) spearheaded the October Revolution of 1917 and inaugurated the 'dictatorship of the proletariat' that was to rule Russia for more than seven decades. Despite the ultimate failure of Soviet communism, his influence endures in Russia and beyond.
paragraphs.comment: Additional biographical context about Lenin; ends the speech material.

title: Why do we want to offer this non-cooperation
speaker: Mahatma Gandhi
summary: Gandhi justifies non-violent non-cooperation as a moral and constitutional duty against British imperial injustice.
introduction: Mahatma Gandhi delivered this speech in August 1920 before a crowd of fifty thousand gathered on the beach at Madras, shortly after formally launching his non-cooperation movement on August 1. The speech followed two major crises: the Amritsar Massacre of April 1919, in which British troops killed at least 379 Indian civilians at a religious festival, and the post-World War I peace terms that dismembered the Ottoman Empire and outraged Indian Muslims who had supported Britain during the war. Gandhi was working to forge Hindu-Muslim unity around a shared moral refusal to cooperate with British rule. His audience was skeptical: many Indians questioned whether non-violence could achieve independence and whether Hindu-Muslim unity was feasible. His argument needed to be simultaneously theological, political, and strategic, convincing people that conscience and self-respect, not merely tactics, demanded non-cooperation.

paragraphs.text: Gandhi made this speech near the very beginning of his long struggle. Following violent campaigns for Indian independence, the Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919, popularly known as the Rowlatt Act, made permanent the suspension of civil liberties enacted during World War I. These developments prompted Gandhi to organize a peaceful, principled resistance movement known as satyagraha ('firmness in truth'). However, this was accompanied by violence in places, leading to the imposition of martial law in the Punjab, and the Amritsar Massacre of April 1919, at which British troops fired into a crowd gathered for a religious festival, killing at least 379.
paragraphs.comment: Contextual background on the Rowlatt Act, satyagraha movement, and Amritsar Massacre.

paragraphs.text: The peace terms presented to Turkey by the Allies following World War I in the Treaty of Sèvres angered Indian Muslims, who launched the Khilafat movement in September 1919 to protect the Turkish Khilafa and save the Ottoman Empire from dismemberment by Britain and her allies. Gandhi supported this movement, and in June 1920 he wrote to the viceroy announcing his intention to start a non-cooperation movement in protest against the treaty. In his letter, he referred to the right of the subject 'to refuse to assist a ruler who misrules'. Supporters of the non-cooperation movement were instructed to refuse to perform government duties, withdraw their children from schools and colleges and establish national schools and colleges. They were to boycott British courts and establish private courts. They were to advocate truth and non-violence at all times and wear Indian home-spun cloth.
paragraphs.comment: Historical context about the Khilafat movement and the non-cooperation campaign's concrete instructions.

paragraphs.text: Gandhi formally launched his non-cooperation movement on 1 August 1920. Soon afterwards, he spoke to a crowd of 50,000 gathered on the beach at Madras. In the speech he explains the importance of the Khilafat movement and the principles of the non-violence movement.
paragraphs.comment: Brief introduction to the Madras speech and its focus on Khilafat and non-violence principles.

paragraphs.text: I have sat here to address you on a most important question…I have come to ask every one of you whether you are ready and willing to give sufficiently for your country's sake, for you country's honour and religion…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Opens by appealing to shared commitment to country, honour, and religion—foundational moral values.

paragraphs.text: What is this non-cooperation, about which you have heard much, and why do we want to offer this non-cooperation? I wish to go for the time being into the way. There are two things before this country: the first and the foremost is the Khilafat question. On this the heart of the Mussulmans 1  of India has become lacerated. British pledges given after the greatest deliberation by the prime minister of England 2  in the name of the English nation, have been dragged into the mire. The promises given to Muslim India…have been broken, and the great religion of Islam has been placed in danger.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Begins explaining non-cooperation by invoking the Khilafat as a shared moral crisis affecting Muslim conscience and Indian brotherhood.

paragraphs.text: The Mussulmans hold - and I venture to think they rightly hold - that, so long as British promises remain unfulfilled, so long is it impossible for them to tender whole-hearted fealty and loyalty to the British connection; and if it is to be a choice for a devout Mussulman between loyalty to the British connection and loyalty to his Code and Prophet, he will not require a second to make his choice - and he has declared his choice. The Mussulmans say frankly, openly, and honourably to the whole world that if the British ministers and the British nation do not fulfil the pledges given to them…it will be impossible for them to retain Islamic loyalty.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Expresses the violated conscience of Muslims: British pledges 'dragged into the mire' and Islam 'placed in danger.'

paragraphs.text: It is a question, then, for the rest of the Indian population to consider whether they want to perform a neighbourly duty by their Mussulman countrymen, and if they do, they have an opportunity of a lifetime, which will not occur for another 100 years, to show their goodwill, fellowship and friendship and to prove what they have been saying for all these long years, that the Mussulman is the brother of the Hindu. If the Hindu regards that before the connection with the British nation comes his natural connection with his Muslim brother, then I say to you that if you find that the Muslim claim is just…you cannot do otherwise than help the Mussulman through and through…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Appeals to Hindus' duty of neighbourly solidarity and appeals to values of goodwill and brotherhood held 'for all these long years.'

paragraphs.text: These are the plain conditions which the Indian Mussulmans have accepted; and it was when they saw that they could accept the proffered aid of the Hindus, that they could always justify the cause and the means before the whole world, that they decided to accept the proffered hand of fellowship.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Notes that Muslims have accepted conditions in good faith and can justify their cause before the world—reinforcing shared principles.

paragraphs.text: It is then for the Hindus and Mohammedans 3  to offer a united front to the whole of the Christian powers of Europe and tell them that weak as India is, India has still got the capacity for preserving her self-respect…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Calls Hindus and Muslims to offer united front and preserve self-respect against European powers.

paragraphs.text: That is the Khilafat in a nut-shell; but you have also got the Punjab. The Punjab has wounded the heart of India as no other question has for the past century. I do not exclude from my calculation the Mutiny of 1857. Whatever hardships India had to suffer during the Mutiny, the insult that was attempted to be offered to her during the passage of the Rowlatt legislation and that which was offered after its passage were unparalleled in Indian history…The House of Commons, the House of Lords, Mr Montagu, 4  the Viceroy of India, 5  every one of them knows what the feeling of India is on this Khilafat question and on that of the Punjab… [but] they are not willing to give the justice which is India's due and which she demands.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details the Punjab as a second wound to Indian heart; calls Amritsar insult 'unparalleled in Indian history' and expresses outrage that justice is withheld.

paragraphs.text: I suggest that…unless we have gained a measure of self-respect at the hands of the British rulers in India, no connection and no friendly intercourse is possible between them and ourselves. I therefore venture to suggest this beautiful and unanswerable method of non-cooperation.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Proposes self-respect as the non-negotiable moral foundation for any future relationship with British rule.

paragraphs.text: I have been told that non-cooperation is unconstitutional. I venture to deny that it is unconstitutional. On the contrary,
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Denies non-cooperation is unconstitutional; begins distinguishing it from rebellion and violence.

paragraphs.text: and it is perfectly constitutional…I do not claim any constitutionality for a rebellion, successful or otherwise, so long as that rebellion means in the ordinary sense of the term, what it does mean - namely wresting justice by violent means. On the contrary, I have said it repeatedly to my countrymen that violence, whatever end it may serve in Europe, will never serve us in India.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Explicitly rejects violence as an acceptable means; non-cooperation is 'constitutional' because it does not 'wrest justice by violent means.'

paragraphs.text: My brother and friend Shaukat Ali 6  believes in methods of violence…but because he recognizes as a true soldier that means of violence are not open to India, he sides with me, accepting my humble assistance, and pledges his word that so long as I am with him and so long as he believes in the doctrine, so long will he not harbour even the idea of violence against any single Englishman or any single man on earth…
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Uses Shaukat Ali as witness to non-violence as a higher moral principle than both violence and passive cooperation.

paragraphs.text: As soon as India accepts the doctrine of the sword, my life as an Indian is finished. It is because I believe in a mission special to India and it is because I believe that the ancients of India, after centuries of experience, have found out that the true thing for any human being on earth is not justice based on violence, but justice based on sacrifice of self, justice based on Yagna and Kurbani. 7  I cling to that doctrine and I shall cling to it for ever. It is for that reason I tell you that whilst my friend believes also in the doctrine of violence and has adopted the doctrine of non-violence as a weapon of the weak, I believe in the doctrine of non-violence as a weapon of the strongest…
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Articulates non-violence as rooted in ancient Indian wisdom and as 'a weapon of the strongest'—a superior moral position.

paragraphs.text: I say to my countrymen: so long as you have a sense of honour and so long as you wish to remain the descendants and defenders of the noble traditions that have been handed to you for generations after generations, it is unconstitutional for you not to non-cooperate and unconstitutional for you to co-operate with a government which has become so unjust as our government has become.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Declares that maintaining honour and tradition demands non-cooperation; framing refusal to cooperate as a moral duty.

paragraphs.text: I am not anti-English; I am not anti-British; I am not anti any government; but I am anti-untruth - anti-humbug and anti-injustice…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Clarifies his position is rooted in opposition to 'untruth, humbug and injustice'—universal moral principles.

paragraphs.text: I had hoped, at the Congress at Amritsar 8  - I am speaking God's truth before you - when I pleaded on bended knees before some of you for co-operation with the government. I had full hope that the British ministers - who are wise, as a rule would placate the Mussulman sentiment; that they would do full justice in the matter of the Punjab atrocities. And therefore I said: Let us return goodwill to the hand of fellowship that has been extended to us, which I then believed was extended to us through the Royal Proclamation. It was on that account that I pleaded for co-operation.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Expresses broken faith in British ministers' wisdom and justice; his previous hope 'obliterated' by their betrayal.

paragraphs.text: But today, that faith having been obliterated by the acts of the British ministers, I
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Continues describing the breach of faith by British ministers regarding Muslim sentiment and Punjab atrocities.

paragraphs.text: am here to plead not for futile obstruction in the legislative council, but for real, substantial non-cooperation, which would paralyse the mightiest government on earth.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Pivots to 'real, substantial non-cooperation' that would paralyse oppressive government—the moral action required.

paragraphs.text: That is what I stand for today. Until we have wrung justice, and until we have wrung our self-respect from unwilling hands and from unwilling pens there can be no cooperation…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Stakes the position clearly: no cooperation until justice and self-respect are reclaimed from unwilling hands.

paragraphs.text: I deny being a visionary. I do not accept the claim of saintliness. I am of the earth, earthy, a common man as much as any one of you, probably much more than you are. I am prone to as many weaknesses as you are…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Claims to be a common person, not a visionary or saint, grounding his moral authority in shared human condition and weakness.

paragraphs.text: I have understood the secret of my own sacred Hinduism, I have learnt the lesson that non-cooperation is the duty not merely of the saint, but it is the duty of every ordinary citizen who - not knowing much, not caring to know much wants to perform his ordinary household functions…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Frames non-cooperation as a spiritual duty for every ordinary citizen in their household functions—universalizing the moral obligation.

paragraphs.text: Whether you belong to the school of violence or non-violence, you will still have to go through the fire of sacrifice and of discipline. May God grant you, may God grant our leaders, the wisdom, the courage and the true knowledge to lead the nation to its cherished goal. May God grant the people of India the right path, the true vision and the ability and the courage to follow this path, difficult and yet easy, of sacrifice.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Closes with prayer for wisdom, courage, and knowledge to follow the difficult path of sacrifice demanded by conscience.

paragraphs.text: back to your towns, to your lands, to your houses, distant but near to my heart, the vigorous impression of this meeting: the flame burning, because that which has not been may because if victory was maimed once, it does not follow that it can be maimed a second 'Carry Keep be,
paragraphs.comment: Fragmented closing text; appears corrupted or incomplete in source material.

paragraphs.text: Benito Mussolini
paragraphs.comment: Off-topic reference to Benito Mussolini with no connection to Gandhi's speech.

paragraphs.text: In 1919, Benito Amilcare Andrea Mussolini (1883-1945) founded the fascist movement, exploiting the widespread disillusionment felt by many Italians in the wake of World War II to promote an extreme nationalism. In 1922, Mussolini was invited by the Italian king, Victor Emmanuel III, to form a government and by 1929, through intimidation, patronage and propaganda, he had turned Italy into a totalitarian state. Ambitious to build an overseas empire, through the 1930s Mussolini increasingly allied his country with Nazi Germany and eventually led Italy to war against the Allies in 1939. Following the Allied landings in Sicily (1943), both the king and his own Fascist Council turned on him and in 1945 he was summarily executed while attempting to flee the country.
paragraphs.comment: Biographical material about Mussolini; editorial content not part of the speech itself.

title: The ballot or the bullet
speaker: Malcolm X
summary: Malcolm X demands Black political power and self-determination over compromise and non-violence.
introduction: Malcolm X delivered 'The Ballot or the Bullet' on April 3, 1964, in Cleveland, Ohio, at a pivotal moment in American racial politics. He had recently broken with the Nation of Islam and was broadening his analysis of Black liberation from religious separatism toward political and economic self-determination. His speech came as Congress debated the Civil Rights Act, legislation Malcolm viewed as Democratic Party window-dressing that rewarded Black voters with token gestures while delivering nothing structural. The audience consisted primarily of Black Americans in Northern urban centers, many increasingly frustrated with the slow pace of change promised by the civil rights mainstream. Malcolm's speech offered a sharp alternative framework: rather than seeking white goodwill or Democratic Party loyalty, Black Americans should recognize that 1964 was 'the most explosive year America has ever witnessed' and act accordingly, with political power or, if that failed, by other means.

paragraphs.text: This powerful speech is a response to the sweeping events of its time - as Malcolm X says here, 1964 'threatens to be the most explosive year America has ever witnessed'. In the run-up to the presidential elections in November, there was an urgent desire among African-Americans for President Lyndon B Johnson to secure passage of the civil rights legislation proposed by President John F Kennedy before he was assassinated. This was partly expressed in the increasing refusal of many black people to accept the programme of non-violent protest endorsed by Martin Luther King.
paragraphs.comment: Contextual framing of the historical moment; provides background rather than rhetorical argument.

paragraphs.text: Also in 1964 came Malcolm's own break from the Nation of Islam and a shift in his stance, in recognition that the struggle for equality was moving from the political to the economic sphere.
paragraphs.comment: Background on Malcolm's break from Nation of Islam; situates his evolving political stance.

paragraphs.text: Malcolm urges assertion over compromise; in place of King's dream of multi-racial harmony, he describes a 'nightmare' of segregation and mistreatment - the only response to which, he urges, must be black unity and black action. Malcolm borrowed the phrase 'the ballot or the bullet' from the 19th-century abolitionist leader Frederick Douglass, but its roots go to the heart of American history, and the anti-colonial war of liberation from England.
paragraphs.comment: Editorial summary of his rhetorical approach; not direct argument from the speech itself.

paragraphs.text: Mr Moderator, Brother Lomax, 1  brothers and sisters, friends and enemies: I just can't believe everyone in here is a friend, and I don't want to leave anybody out. The question tonight, as I understand it, is 'The Negro Revolt, and Where Do We Go from Here?' or 'What Next?' In my little humble way of understanding it, it points toward either the ballot or the bullet…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Opens by establishing inclusive community ('brothers and sisters, friends and enemies') and framing a shared question about the path forward.

paragraphs.text: …I'm not here tonight to discuss my religion. I'm not here to try and change your religion. I'm not here to argue or discuss anything that we differ about, because it's time for us to submerge our differences and realize that it is best for us to first see that we have the same problem, a common problem, a problem that will make you catch hell whether you're a Baptist, or a Methodist, or a Muslim, or a nationalist. Whether you're educated or illiterate, whether you live on the boulevard or in the alley, you're going to catch hell just like I am. We're all in the same boat and we all are going to catch the same hell from the same man. He just happens to be a white man…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Dissolves theological divisions to reveal common material hardship; all suffer 'catch hell' regardless of religion or social status.

paragraphs.text: Now in speaking like this, it doesn't mean that we're anti-white, but it does mean we're anti-exploitation, we're anti-degradation, we're anti-oppression. And if the white man doesn't want us to be anti-him, let him stop oppressing and exploiting and degrading us…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Reframes opposition as principled resistance to exploitation, not racial antagonism, appealing to shared standards of justice.

paragraphs.text: If we have differences, let us differ in the closet. When we come out in front, let us not have anything to argue about until we get finished arguing with the man. If the late President Kennedy could get together with Khrushchev and exchange some wheat, 2  we certainly have more in common with each other than Kennedy and Khrushchev had with each other.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Uses Kennedy-Khrushchev analogy to establish that Black Americans have more legitimate shared interest than Cold War adversaries.

paragraphs.text: If we don't do something real soon, I think you'll have to agree that we're going to be forced either to use the ballot or the bullet. It's one or the other in 1964. It isn't that time is running out - time has run out!
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Issues urgent warning that 1964 forces a binary choice; time for deliberation has expired.

paragraphs.text: Nineteen sixty-four threatens to be the most explosive year America has ever witnessed.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Names 1964 as 'most explosive year'; sets stage for escalating moral indictment.

paragraphs.text: The most explosive year. Why? It's a political year. It's the year when all of the white politicians will be back in the so-called negro community, jiving you and me for some votes. The year when all of the white political crooks will be right back in your and my community with their false promises, building up our hopes for a let-down, with their trickery and their treachery, with their false promises which they don't intend to keep. As they nourish these dissatisfactions, it can only lead to one thing, an explosion; and now we have the type of black man on the scene in America today - I'm sorry, Brother Lomax - who just doesn't intend to turn the other cheek any longer…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs political duplicity: false promises, trickery, treachery leading to inevitable explosion of anger.

paragraphs.text: I'm not a politician, not even a student of politics; in fact, I'm not a student of much of anything. I'm not a Democrat. I'm not a Republican, and I don't even consider myself an American. If you and I were Americans, there'd be no problem. Those honkies 3  that just got off the boat, they're already Americans; Polacks 4 are already Americans; the Italian refugees are already Americans. Everything that came out of Europe, every blue-eyed thing, is already an American. And as long as you and I have been over here, we aren't Americans yet.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Questions Black American status and belonging in America despite centuries of presence; reveals systematic exclusion.

paragraphs.text: Well, I am one who doesn't believe in deluding myself. I'm not going to sit at your table and watch you eat, with nothing on my plate, and call myself a diner. Sitting at the table doesn't make you a diner, unless you eat some of what's on that plate. Being here in America doesn't make you an American. Being born here in America doesn't make you an American. Why, if birth made you American, you wouldn't need any legislation; you wouldn't need any amendments to the Constitution; you wouldn't be faced with civil rights filibustering in Washington, DC, right now. They don't have to pass civil rights legislation to make a Polack an American.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Uses dinner table metaphor to expose gap between nominal inclusion and actual participation in rights and benefits.

paragraphs.text: One of the 22 million black people who are the victims of democracy, nothing but disguised hypocrisy…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Declares Black Americans 'victims of democracy, nothing but disguised hypocrisy'—names the core moral betrayal.

paragraphs.text: These 22 million victims are waking up. Their eyes are coming open. They're beginning to see what they used to only look at. They're becoming politically mature…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Shows Black Americans awakening to political reality and developing mature understanding of power.

paragraphs.text: - …With Kennedy and Nixon when they ran for president, it was so close they had to count all over again. 5 Well, what does this mean? It means that when white people are evenly divided, and black people have a bloc of votes of their own: it is left up to them to determine who's going to sit in the White House and who's going to be in the dog house.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Demonstrates that Black voting bloc holds decisive power in close elections; contrasts this power with lack of benefit received.

paragraphs.text: It was the black man's vote that put the present administration in Washington, DC. Your vote, your dumb vote, your ignorant vote, your wasted vote put in an administration in Washington, DC, that has seen fit to pass every kind of legislation imaginable, saving you until last, then filibustering on top of that.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Condemns Black voters for being taken for granted; accuses them of supporting administrators who betray them.

paragraphs.text: And your and my leaders have the audacity to run around clapping their hands and talk about how much progress we're making. And what a good president we have. If he wasn't good in Texas, he sure can't be good in Washington, DC… 6
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Attacks Black leaders for celebrating false progress and touting a president who has failed them.

paragraphs.text: And these negro leaders have the audacity to go and have some coffee in the White House with a Texan, a southern cracker - that's all he is - and then come out and tell you and me that he's going to be better for us because, since he's from the South, he knows how to deal with the Southerners. What kind of logic is that? Let Eastland 7 be president, he's from the South too. He should be better able to deal with them than Johnson.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Exposes sophistry: southern president should be no more favorable than any other; leaders deceive themselves and followers.

paragraphs.text: In this present administration, they have in the House of Representatives 257 Democrats to only 177 Republicans. They control two-thirds of the House vote. Why can't they pass something that will help you and me? In the Senate, there are 67 senators who are of the Democratic Party. Only 33 of them are Republicans. Why, the Democrats have got the government sewed up, and you're the one who sewed it up for them.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Presents political arithmetic: Democrats control overwhelming legislative majorities yet cannot pass civil rights legislation.

paragraphs.text: And what have they given you for it? Four years in office, and just now getting around to some civil rights legislation…They get all the negro vote, and after they get it, the negro gets nothing in return. All they did when they got to Washington was give a few big negroes big jobs. Those big negroes didn't need big jobs; they already had jobs. That's camouflage, that's trickery, that's treachery, window-dressing…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Lists empty returns on Black political investment: token appointments, window-dressing, promises without delivery.

paragraphs.text: That's why, in 1964, it's time now for you and me to become more politically mature and realize what the ballot is for; what we're supposed to get when we cast a ballot; and that if we don't cast a ballot, it's going to end up in a situation where we're going to have to cast a bullet. It's either a ballot or a bullet…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Pivots from outrage to action: become politically mature, understand what ballot power means, or embrace alternative.

paragraphs.text: You don't need to go to the employer alone, it is the government itself, the government of America, that is responsible for the oppression and exploitation and degradation of black people in this country. And you should drop it in their lap. This government has failed the negro. This so-called democracy has failed the negro. And all these white liberals have definitely failed the negro…
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Redirects accountability from employers to government; demands moral agency in naming who is responsible.

paragraphs.text: You take the people who are in this audience right now. They're poor. We're all poor as individuals. Our weekly salary individually amounts to hardly anything. But if you take the salary of everyone in here collectively, it'll fill up a whole lot of baskets. It's a lot of wealth. If you can collect the wages of just these people right here for a year, you'll be rich - richer than rich. When you look at it like that, think how rich Uncle Sam had to become, not with this handful, but millions of black people. Your and my mother and father, who didn't work an eight-hour shift, but worked from 'can't see' in the morning until 'can't see' at night, and worked for nothing, making the white man rich, making Uncle Sam rich. This is our investment. This is our contribution, our blood.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Quantifies collective Black wealth and labor extraction; makes economic exploitation visible and calculable.

paragraphs.text: Not only did we give of our free labour, we gave of our blood. Every time he had a call to arms, we were the first ones in uniform. We died on every battlefield the white man had. We have made a greater sacrifice than anybody who's standing up in America today. We have made a greater contribution and have collected less…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs blood sacrifice in every American war; contrasts massive contribution with minimal compensation.

paragraphs.text: I might stop right here to point out one thing. Whenever you're going after something that belongs to you, anyone who's depriving you of the right to have it is a criminal. Understand that. Whenever you are going after something that is yours, you are within your legal rights to lay claim to it. And anyone who puts forth any effort to deprive you of that which is yours is breaking the law, is a criminal. And this was pointed out by the Supreme Court decision. It outlawed segregation.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Appeals to legal and moral principle: those defending their own rights are within justice; those opposing are criminals.

paragraphs.text: Which means segregation is against the law.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Reiterates legal fact: segregation outlawed; makes law the standard against which to measure conduct.

paragraphs.text: Which means a segregationist is breaking the law. A segregationist is a criminal. You can't label him as anything other than that. And when you demonstrate against segregation, the law is on your side. The Supreme Court is on your side.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Exposes hypocrisy: law opposes segregation but police enforce it with violence against those exercising legal rights.

paragraphs.text: Now, who is it that opposes you in carrying out the law? The police department itself. With police dogs and clubs. Whenever you demonstrate against segregation, whether it is segregated education, segregated housing, or anything else, the law is on your side, and anyone who stands in the way is not the law any longer. They are breaking the law; they are not representatives of the law.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Instructs listeners to defend themselves when rights are violated; frames self-defense as moral obligation grounded in law.

paragraphs.text: Any time you demonstrate against segregation and a man has the audacity to put a police dog on you, kill that dog, kill him, I'm telling you, kill that dog. I say it, if they put me in jail tomorrow, kill that dog. Then you'll put a stop to it. Now, if these white people in here don't want to see that kind of action, get down and tell the mayor to tell the police department to pull the dogs in. That's all you have to do. If you don't do it, someone else will.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Appeals to conscience of future generations; demands uncompromising stand rooted in justice rather than non-violence principle.

paragraphs.text: If you don't take this kind of stand, your little children will grow up and look at you and think 'shame'.
