If you don't take an uncompromising stand, I don't mean go out and get violent; but at the same time you should never be non-violent unless you run into some non-violence. I'm non-violent with those who are nonviolent with me. But when you drop that violence on me, then you've made me go insane, and I'm not responsible for what I do. And that's the way every negro should get.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Affirms moral imperative to act according to legal and moral rights; reciprocal sacrifice as condition of justice.

paragraphs.text: Any time you know you're within the law, within your legal rights, within your moral rights, in accord with justice, then die for what you believe in. But don't die alone. Let your dying be reciprocal.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Defines equality as reciprocity; establishes moral standard by which to judge American conduct.

paragraphs.text: This is what is meant by equality. What's good for the goose is good for the gander…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Condemns America's global hypocrisy: poses as free world leader while committing racial violence domestically.

paragraphs.text: He's the earth's number-one hypocrite. He has the audacity - yes, he has imagine him posing as the leader of the free world. The free world! And you over here singing 'We Shall Overcome'. Expand the civil rights struggle to the level of human rights. Take it into the United Nations, where our African brothers can throw their weight on our side, where our Asian brothers can throw their weight on our side, where our Latin-American brothers can throw their weight on our side, and where 800 million Chinamen are sitting there waiting to throw their weight on our side.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Expands moral struggle from civil rights to human rights; calls for international mobilization of moral force.

paragraphs.text: Let the world know how bloody his hands are. Let the world know the hypocrisy that's practised over here. Let it be the ballot or the bullet. Let him know that it must be the ballot or the bullet.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Final urgent call to expose American violence and hypocrisy to world; reasserts binary: ballot or bullet.

paragraphs.text: 'Perhaps it is the least understood fact of American political life: the enormous buried violence of women in this country today:
paragraphs.comment: Epigraph quote about women's 'buried violence'; thematic echo rather than part of speech proper.

paragraphs.text: Friedan Betty
paragraphs.comment: Attribution of epigraph.

paragraphs.text: Elizabeth Naomi Friedan née Goldstein (1921-2006) was founder and first president of the National Association for Women (1966), and headed the National Women's Strike for Equality (1970). Her best-selling book The Feminine Mystique (1963) analysed the role of women in American society and articulated their frustrations.
paragraphs.comment: Biographical note on Betty Friedan; contextual material appended to collection.

title: Apartheid's final solution
speaker: Desmond Tutu
summary: Tutu condemns apartheid as systematic injustice and moral evil requiring immediate dismantling.
introduction: Desmond Tutu delivered this speech on December 11, 1984, in Oslo, Norway, upon accepting the Nobel Peace Prize, an honor that represented international recognition of his role as apartheid South Africa's moral conscience. At the time, apartheid remained firmly entrenched; the new South African constitution introduced in 1983 had extended limited participation to Indians and so-called 'Coloured' people while entirely excluding Black South Africans. Tutu, an Anglican bishop who refused to stay silent despite personal risk, used the world's highest-profile platform to expose apartheid's mechanisms and moral consequences. His audience was simultaneously the Nobel Committee, the assembled dignitaries in Oslo, and, through global media, the international community whose investment, trade, and diplomatic recognition sustained apartheid. His religious authority gave his condemnation an intensity that purely political critics could not match: he was not arguing that apartheid was poor policy but that it was a sin against God.

paragraphs.text: Well known as an outspoken critic of South African apartheid, Archbishop Tutu was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984. He used this acceptance speech to condemn South Africa's 'racist dream', and to scorn the limited concessions of the country's new constitution, introduced the previous year.
paragraphs.comment: Contextual framing by anthology editor; not from Tutu's speech proper.

paragraphs.text: Nelson Mandela (who would receive the Nobel Peace Prize in 1993) once remarked of his ally: 'Sometimes strident, often tender, never afraid and seldom without humour, Desmond Tutu's voice will always be the voice of the voiceless.'
paragraphs.comment: Contextual framing by anthology editor; Mandela quote about Tutu.

paragraphs.text: Presenting the award, Egil Aarvik, chairman of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, spoke of Tutu's determination that peace should triumph over violence. He recalled seeing an example of Tutu's ministry during television coverage of a massacre in Johannesburg: 'After the police vehicles had driven away with their prisoners, Desmond Tutu stood and spoke to a frightened and bitter congregation: 'Do not hate,' he said. 'Let us choose the peaceful way to freedom.''
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Aarvik recalls Tutu's ministry embodying non-hatred and peaceful resistance, establishing moral consensus against violence.

paragraphs.text: Nonetheless, Tutu is a forceful speaker. Having described individual cases and their tragic consequences for both black and white South Africans, he turns briefly lyrical, before dissecting the iniquities of apartheid.
paragraphs.comment: Editorial transition; sets stage for Tutu's lyrical description of South Africa.

paragraphs.text: with radiant sunshine, golden sunshine. There is enough of the good things that come from God's bounty, there is enough for everyone, but apartheid has confirmed some in their selfishness, causing them to grasp greedily a disproportionate share, the lion's share, because of their power.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Tutu invokes God's bounty and natural beauty as shared human inheritance, establishing ethical baseline that resources belong to all.

paragraphs.text: They have taken 87 per cent of the land, though being only about 20 per cent of our population. The rest have had to make do with the remaining 13 per cent. Apartheid 1  has decreed the politics of exclusion. Seventy-three per cent of the population is excluded from any meaningful participation in the political decision-making processes of the land of their birth.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Presents concrete evidence: 20% of population claims 87% of land, 73% of population excluded from political participation.

paragraphs.text: The new constitution 2 …perpetuates by law and entrenches white minority rule. Blacks are expected to exercise their political ambitions in unviable, povertystricken, arid, bantustan 3 homelands, ghettoes of misery, inexhaustible reservoirs of cheap black labour, bantustans into which South Africa is being Balkanized.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details constitutional injustice and bantustan system, showing legal machinery of apartheid enforces exclusion.

paragraphs.text: Blacks are systematically being stripped of their South African citizenship and being turned into aliens in the land of their birth.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Illustrates loss of citizenship as deliberate dehumanization of Black South Africans.

paragraphs.text: This is apartheid's final solution, just as Nazism had its final solution for the Jews in Hitler's Aryan madness. The South African government is smart. Aliens can claim but very few rights, least of all political rights.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Compares apartheid to Nazi genocide, invoking historical moral gravity and demanding international recognition of equivalent evil.

paragraphs.text: In pursuance of apartheid's ideological racist dream, over three million of God's children have been uprooted from their homes, which have been demolished, whilst they have then been dumped in the bantustan homeland resettlement camps. I say dumped advisedly: only things or rubbish is dumped, not human beings. Apartheid has, however, ensured that God's children, just because they are black, should be treated as if they were things, and not as of infinite value as being created in the image of God.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs forced removals of millions with vivid language ('dumped') contrasting human worth with object treatment.

paragraphs.text: These dumping grounds are far from where work and food can be procured easily. Children starve, suffer from the often irreversible consequences of malnutrition - this happens to them not accidentally, but by deliberate government policy. They starve in a land that could be the bread basket of Africa, a land that normally is a net exporter of food.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Exposes deliberate government starvation policy amid abundance, showing moral intent behind suffering.

paragraphs.text: The father leaves his family in the bantustan homeland, there eking out a miserable existence, whilst he, if he is lucky, goes to the so-called white man's town as a migrant, to live an unnatural life in a single-sex hostel for 11 months of the year, being prey there to prostitution, drunkenness and worse.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Describes systemic family destruction through migrant labor policy, emphasizing human cost.

paragraphs.text: This migratory labour policy is declared government policy, and has been condemned…as a cancer in our society.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Reinforces previous point about deliberate policy causing social pathology.

paragraphs.text: Apartheid has spawned discriminatory education, such as Bantu Education, education for serfdom, ensuring that the government spends only about onetenth on one black child per annum for education what it spends on a white child. It is education that is decidedly separate and unequal. It is wantonly wasteful of human resources, because so many of God's children are prevented, by deliberate government policy, from attaining to their fullest potential…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details education inequality (1/10th spending per Black child) as calculated waste of human potential.

paragraphs.text: Apartheid is upheld by a phalanx of iniquitous laws, such as the Population Registration Act, which decrees that all South Africans must be classified ethnically and duly registered according to these race categories. Many times, in the same family one child has been classified white whilst another, with a slightly darker hue, has been classified coloured, with all the horrible consequences for the latter of being shut out from membership of a greatly privileged caste. There have, as a result, been several child suicides.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs Population Registration Act dividing families by race, including child suicides resulting from such classification.

paragraphs.text: This is too high a price to pay for racial purity, for it is doubtful whether any end, however desirable, can justify such a means. There are laws such as the Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Act, which regard marriages between a white and a person of another race as illegal. Race becomes an impediment to a valid marriage. Two persons who have fallen in love are prevented by race from consummating their love in the marriage bond. Something beautiful is made to be sordid and ugly…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Condemns laws prohibiting interracial marriage as making 'something beautiful...sordid and ugly.'

paragraphs.text: There are the laws which permit the indefinite detention of persons whom the Minister of Law and Order has decided are a threat to the security of the state. They are detained at his pleasure, in solitary confinement, without access to their family, their own doctor or a lawyer. That is severe punishment when the evidence apparently available to the minister has not been tested in an open court - perhaps it could stand up to such rigorous scrutiny, perhaps not; we are never to know.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details indefinite detention without due process, showing government abuse of judicial power.

paragraphs.text: It is a far too convenient device for a repressive regime, and the minister would have to be extra-special not to succumb to the temptation to circumvent the awkward process of testing his evidence in an open court, and thus he lets his power under the law to be open to the abuse where he is both judge and prosecutor. Many - too many - have died mysteriously in detention. All this is too costly in terms of human lives.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Emphasizes deaths in custody and systemic abuse, quantifying human cost of repression.

paragraphs.text: The minister is able, too, to place people under banning orders without being subjected to the annoyance of the checks and balances of due process. A banned person for three or five years becomes a non-person, who cannot be quoted during the period of her banning order. She cannot attend a gathering, which means more than one other person. Two persons together talking to a banned person are a gathering! She cannot attend the wedding or funeral of even her own child without special permission. She must be at home from 6pm of one day to 6am of the next and on all public holidays, and from 6pm on Fridays until 6am on Mondays for three years. She cannot go on holiday outside the magisterial area to which she has been confined. She cannot go to the cinema, nor to a picnic.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs oppressive banning orders destroying freedom of movement, association, and family participation.

paragraphs.text: That is severe punishment, inflicted without the evidence allegedly justifying it being made available to the banned person, nor having it scrutinized in a court of law. It is a serious erosion and violation of basic human rights, of which blacks have precious few in the land of their birth. They do not enjoy the rights of freedom of movement and association. They do not enjoy freedom of security of tenure, the right to participate in the making of decisions that affect their lives. In short, this land, richly endowed in so many ways, is sadly lacking in justice.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Concludes outrage section by contrasting documented rights violations with ideals of justice and human freedom.

paragraphs.text: Once a Zambian and a South African, it is said, were talking. The Zambian then boasted about their Minister of Naval Affairs. The South African asked, 'But you have no navy, no access to the sea. How then can you have a Minister of Naval Affairs?' The Zambian retorted, 'Well, in South Africa you have a Minister of Justice, don't you?'
paragraphs.comment: Rhetorical joke about justice in South Africa, puncturing tension but not advancing framework argument.

paragraphs.text: It is against this system that our people have sought to protest peacefully since 1912 at least, with the founding of the African National Congress. 4  They have used the conventional methods of peaceful protest - petitions, demonstrations, deputations, and even a passive resistance campaign. A tribute to our people's commitment to peaceful change is the fact that the only South Africans to win the Nobel Peace Prize are both black. 5
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: References 72 years of peaceful protest and Black Nobel laureates, establishing shared value of nonviolence.

paragraphs.text: Our people are peace-loving to a fault. The response of the authorities has been an escalating intransigence and violence, the violence of police dogs, tear gas, detention without trial, exile and even death. Our people protested peacefully against the Pass Laws 6  in 1960, and 69 of them were killed on March 21,1960, at Sharpeville, many shot in the back running away. 7
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Contrasts Black nonviolence with government violence; catalogs Sharpeville massacre as proof of brutal response.

paragraphs.text: Our children protested against inferior education, singing songs and displaying placards and marching peacefully. Many in 1976, on June 16 and subsequent times, were killed or imprisoned. 8
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details 1976 student uprising and killings, showing repeated patterns of violence against peaceful protest.

paragraphs.text: Over 500 people died in that uprising. Many children went into exile. The whereabouts of many are unknown to their parents…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Quantifies Soweto uprising deaths (500+) and lost children, emphasizing scale of tragedy.

paragraphs.text: There has been little revulsion or outrage at this wanton destruction of human life in the West. In parenthesis, can somebody please explain to me something that has puzzled me? When a priest goes missing and is subsequently found dead, the media in the West carry his story in very extensive coverage. 9  I am glad that the death of one person can cause so much concern. But in the selfsame week when this priest is found dead, the South African Police kill 24 blacks who had been participating in the protest, and 6,000 blacks are sacked for being similarly involved, and you are lucky to get that much coverage.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Directly indicts Western media and audience for ignoring Black deaths while covering White deaths—a moral challenge to international listeners.

paragraphs.text: Are we being told something I do not want to believe - that we blacks are expendable and that blood is thicker than water; that when it comes to the crunch, you cannot trust whites, that they will club together against us? I don't want to believe that is the message being conveyed to us.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Frames audience complicity: rhetorical question about whether Western indifference signals Black expendability and racial betrayal.

paragraphs.text: Be that as it may, we see before us a land bereft of much justice, and therefore without peace and security. Unrest is endemic, and will remain an unchanging feature of the South African scene until apartheid, the root cause of it all, is
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Restates the gap: current South Africa bereft of justice, without peace or security until apartheid ends.

paragraphs.text: At this time, the army is being quartered on the civilian population. There is a civil war being waged. South Africans are on either side. When the African National Congress and the Pan-Africanist Congress 10  were banned in 1960, they declared that they had no option but to carry out the armed struggle. We in the South African Council of Churches have said we are opposed to all forms of violence - that of a repressive and unjust system, and that of those who seek to overthrow that system. However, we have added that we understand those who say they have had to adopt what is a last resort for them…
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Describes civil war and armed struggle as inevitable response to 1960 bans, showing how repression generates violence.

paragraphs.text: I have spoken extensively about South Africa, first because it is the land I know best; but because it is also a microcosm of the world and an example of what is to be found in other lands in differing degree…Because there is global insecurity, nations are engaged in a mad arms race, spending billions of dollars wastefully on instruments of destruction, when millions are starving. And yet, just a fraction of what is expended so obscenely on defence budgets would make the difference in enabling God's children to fill their stomachs, be educated, and given the chance to lead fulfilled and happy lives. We have the capacity to feed ourselves several times over, but we are daily haunted by the spectacle of the gaunt dregs of humanity shuffling along in endless queues, with bowls to collect what the charity of the world has provided, too little too late.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Expands framework from South Africa to global injustice: arms race vs. starvation, wealth inequality, reframes as universal moral failing.

paragraphs.text: God created us for fellowship. God created us so that we should form the human family, existing together because we were made for one another. We are not made for an exclusive self-sufficiency but for interdependence, and we break the law of our being at our peril…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Invokes theological anthropology: God created humans for fellowship and interdependence, not self-sufficiency.

paragraphs.text: Unless we work assiduously so that all of God's children, our brothers and sisters, members of our one human family, all will enjoy basic human rights, the right to a fulfilled life, the right of movement, of work, the freedom to be fully human, with a humanity measured by nothing less than the humanity of Jesus Christ Himself, then we are on the road inexorably to self-destruction; we are not far from global suicide - and yet it could be so different.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Issues urgent moral imperative: work assiduously so all enjoy human rights and full humanity measured by Christ's standard.

paragraphs.text: When will we learn that human beings are of infinite value because they have been created in the image of God, and that it is a blasphemy to treat them as if they were less than this, and to do so ultimately recoils on those who do this? In dehumanizing others, they are themselves dehumanized. Perhaps oppression dehumanizes the oppressor as much as, if not more than, the oppressed. They need each other to become truly free, to become human…
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Reiterates foundational moral truth: humans have infinite value as created in God's image; dehumanizing others dehumanizes oppressor.

paragraphs.text: Let us work to be peacemakers, those given a wonderful share in Our Lord's ministry of reconciliation. If we want peace, so we have been told, let us work for justice.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Calls audience to become peacemakers and workers for justice, framing activism as God's work.

paragraphs.text: God calls us to be fellow workers with Him, so that we can extend his kingdom of shalom, 12 of justice, of goodness, of compassion, of caring, of sharing, of laughter, joy and reconciliation, so that the kingdoms of this world will become the Kingdom of our God and of his Christ, and he shall reign for ever and ever. Amen.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Final vision: God calls humanity to extend kingdom of justice, compassion, reconciliation—highest aspirational call to action.

title: They thought that the bullets would silence us
speaker: Malala Yousafzai
summary: Malala advocates for education rights and women's empowerment through moral appeals and personal testimony.
introduction: Malala Yousafzai delivered this speech to the United Nations General Assembly on July 12, 2013, her sixteenth birthday, just nine months after being shot in the head by a Taliban gunman for her activism on behalf of girls' education. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon had dubbed the occasion 'Malala Day,' and she addressed the packed General Assembly Hall while wearing a shawl that had belonged to Benazir Bhutto. Malala made education her central demand while framing it as a matter of conscience that the international community had an obligation to act upon. Her speech was delivered in support of the UN's 'Education First' initiative and became one of the most watched UN addresses in the organization's history. Her youth, her survival, and her moral clarity made her argument nearly impossible for world leaders to dismiss.

paragraphs.text: The world already knew about the extraordinary courage and determination of Malala Yousafzai long before the 'Youth Takeover' event at the United Nations headquarters, dubbed Malala Day in her honour. But few can have imagined that she would deliver this speech with such composure and clarity, just nine months after a near-fatal injury. Standing almost perfectly still, she spoke with quiet confidence and dignity under the world's gaze. Her key message - delivered in support of the United Nations' 'Education First' initiative - was the importance of education and the right of everyone to receive it.
paragraphs.comment: Editor's introduction describing the context and speaker; not part of Malala's speech itself.

paragraphs.text: She establishes her credentials as a devout Muslim at the beginning of her speech, but later cites the figureheads of other world religions, as well as secular figures who have espoused non-violent activism. Islam, she insists, is a peaceful religion which encourages learning for all children. She repudiates hatred for her cowardly would-be assassin, instead calling on the Taliban to allow their children to be educated.
paragraphs.comment: Continued editorial summary of the speech; not Malala's spoken words.

paragraphs.text: In the name of God, the Most Beneficent, The Most Merciful. 1
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Opening invocation of God signals shared spiritual grounding before a diverse global audience.

paragraphs.text: Honourable UN Secretary General Mr Ban Ki-moon, 2
paragraphs.comment: Formal salutation acknowledging dignitaries; no rhetorical label applies.

paragraphs.text: Respected President General Assembly Vuk Jeremić, 3
paragraphs.comment: Continuation of formal salutations to dignitaries.

paragraphs.text: Honourable UN envoy for global education Mr Gordon Brown, 4
paragraphs.comment: Continuation of formal salutations to dignitaries.

paragraphs.text: Respected elders and my dear brothers and sisters;
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Inclusive address framing the audience as a unified moral community of equals.

paragraphs.text: As-salamu alaykum . 5 [Repeated in response by some audience members.]
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: The traditional Islamic greeting of peace, which drew a collective response, reinforcing shared values.

paragraphs.text: Today, it is an honour for me to be speaking again after a long time. 6  Being here with such honourable people is a great moment in my life, and it's an honour for me that today I am wearing today a shawl of Benazir Bhutto Shaheed. 7
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Invoking Benazir Bhutto—a martyred leader for democracy—connects Malala's cause to a respected moral legacy.

paragraphs.text: I don't know where to begin my speech. I don't know what people would be expecting me to say.
paragraphs.comment: A moment of honest vulnerability that humanizes the speaker before launching into the argument.

paragraphs.text: But first of all, thank you to God for whom we all are equal and thank you to every person who has prayed for my fast recovery and a new life. I cannot believe how much love people have shown me. I have received thousands of good wish cards and gifts from all over the world. Thank you to all of them. Thank you to the children whose innocent words encouraged me. Thank you to my elders whose prayers strengthened me.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Affirming God's universal equality and global solidarity establishes shared moral values across the audience.

paragraphs.text: I would like to thank my nurses, doctors and the staff of the hospitals in Pakistan and the UK, and the UAE government, 8  who have helped me get better and recover my strength. I fully support Mr Ban Ki-moon, the Secretary-General, in his Global Education First Initiative and the work of the UN Special Envoy, Mr Gordon Brown, and the respected President General Assembly Vuk Jeremić. I thank all of them for the leadership they continue to give. They continue to inspire all of us to action.
paragraphs.comment: Acknowledgment of institutional support and alignment with the UN's mission; primarily procedural.

paragraphs.text: There are hundreds of human rights activists and social workers who are not only speaking for their rights, but who are struggling to achieve their goals of peace, education and equality. Thousands of people have been killed by the terrorists and millions have been injured. I am just one of them.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Places her personal suffering in the context of mass atrocity, widening the scope of injustice the audience must confront.

paragraphs.text: So here I stand…so here I stand, one girl among many.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The deliberate repetition underscores that her survival is itself a form of testimony against those who would silence dissent.

paragraphs.text: I speak not for myself, but for those without voice can be heard.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Frames herself as a vessel for those whose silencing constitutes the moral outrage being demonstrated.

paragraphs.text: Those who have fought for their rights:
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Introduces the community of the silenced whose struggle gives moral weight to her testimony.

paragraphs.text: Their right to live in peace. Their right to be treated with [slight fluff] dignity. Their right to equality of opportunity. Their right to be educated.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Enumerating universal rights frames education as belonging to the same moral category as peace and dignity.

paragraphs.text: Dear friends, on the 9th of October 2012, the Taliban shot me on the left side of my forehead. They shot my friends too. They thought that the bullets would silence us. But they failed. And out of that silence came thousands of voices.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The specific, unflinching account of her shooting is the emotional and moral core of the outrage being demonstrated.

paragraphs.text: The terrorists thought that they would change my aims and stop my ambitions but nothing changed in my life except this: weakness, fear and hopelessness died. Strength, power and courage was born.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Transforms the attempt to silence her into evidence of the terrorists' moral failure and her cause's resilience.

paragraphs.text: [Prolonged applause and cheers.] I am the same Malala. My ambitions are the same. My hopes are the same. And my dreams are the same.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Insisting on her unchanged identity implicitly indicts the violence that sought to alter it.

paragraphs.text: Dear sisters and brothers, I'm not against anyone. Neither am I here to speak in terms of personal revenge against the Taliban or any other terrorist group. I am here to speak up for the right of education of every child. I want education for the sons and daughters of the Taliban and all terrorists and extremists.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Renouncing revenge and extending educational advocacy even to enemies grounds her argument in universal, principled compassion.

paragraphs.text: I do not even hate the Talib who shot me. Even if there is a gun in my hand and he stands in front of me, I would not shoot him. This is the compassion that I have learnt from Muhammad, the prophet of mercy, and Jesus Christ and Lord Buddha. This is the legacy of change that I have inherited from Martin Luther King, Nelson Mandela and Muhammad Ali Jinnah. 9  This is… [Interrupted by applause.] This is the philosophy of non-violence that I have learnt from Gandhiji, 10 Bacha Khan 11  and Mother Teresa. 12  And this is the forgiveness that I have learned from my father and from my mother This is what my soul is telling me: be peaceful and love everyone.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Drawing on Islam, Christianity, Buddhism, and secular moral heroes weaves a universal ethical fabric that obligates the entire audience.

paragraphs.text: Dear sisters and brothers, we realise the importance of light when we see darkness. We realise the importance of our voice when we are silenced. In the same way, when we were in Swat 13 , the north of Pakistan, we realised the importance of pens and books when we saw the guns.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The light/darkness metaphor contrasts the moral ideal of education with the reality of violent suppression.

paragraphs.text: The wise saying, 'The pen is mightier than sword' 14  was true. The extremists were and they are afraid of books and pens.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Contrasting the pen with the sword highlights that the moral ideal of knowledge is what the violent actors most fear.

paragraphs.text: The power of education, the power of education frightens them. They are afraid of women. The power of the voice of women frightens them. And that is why they killed 14 innocent students in the recent attack in Quetta. 15 And that is why they killed female teachers and polio workers in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. That is why they are blasting schools every day. Because they were and they are afraid of change, afraid of equality that we will bring into our society.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Listing specific atrocities—killed students, murdered teachers, bombed schools—intensifies the catalog of injustice requiring condemnation.

paragraphs.text: And I remember that there was a boy in our school who was asked by a journalist, 'Why are the Taliban against education?' He answered very simply, by pointing to his book. He said, 'A Talib doesn't know what is written inside this book.' They think that God is a tiny, little conservative being who would send girls to the Hell just because of going to school. The terrorists are misusing the name of Islam and Pashtun society for their own personal benefits. Pakistan is peace-loving, democratic country. Pashtuns want education for their daughters and sons. And Islam is a religion of peace, humanity and brotherhood. Islam says it's not only each child's right to get education, rather it's their duty and responsibility.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Reclaiming Islam as a religion of education and peace dismantles the extremists' justification and reasserts shared moral values.

paragraphs.text: Honourable Secretary-General, peace is necessary for education. In many parts of the world, especially Pakistan and Afghanistan, terrorism, wars and conflicts stop children to go to their schools. We are really tired of these wars. Women and children are suffering in many ways in many parts of the world. In India, innocent and poor children are victims of child labour. Many schools have been destroyed in Nigeria. 16 People in Afghanistan have been affected by the hurdles of extremism for decades. Young girls have to do domestic child labour and are forced to get married at early age. Poverty, ignorance, injustice, racism and the deprivation of basic rights are the main problems faced by both men and women.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: A global survey of children denied education by war, labour, and extremism extends the moral outrage beyond a single country.

paragraphs.text: Dear fellows, today I am focusing on women's rights and girls' education because they are suffering the most. There was a time when women social activists asked men to stand up for their rights. But, this time, we will do it by ourselves. I'm not telling men to step away from speaking for women's rights; rather I am focusing on women to be independent to fight for themselves.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Contrasting past dependence on male advocacy with the moral ideal of women's self-determined empowerment.

paragraphs.text: So, dear sisters and brothers, now it's time to speak up.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: A direct, pivotal call marking the shift from testimony and analysis to a summons for collective action.

paragraphs.text: So today, we call upon the world leaders to change their strategic policies in favour of peace and prosperity.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: First in a series of explicit demands that world leaders align their policies with the moral imperatives she has established.

paragraphs.text: We call upon the world leaders that all the peace deals must protect women's and children's rights. A deal that goes against the rights of women is unacceptable.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Demands that peace negotiations be held to the moral standard of protecting the most vulnerable.

paragraphs.text: We call upon all governments to ensure free compulsory education all over the world for every child. We call upon all the governments to fight against terrorism and violence, to protect children from brutality and harm.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Calls governments to fulfill the moral obligation to guarantee education and safety for every child globally.

paragraphs.text: We call upon the developed nations to support the expansion of educational opportunities for girls in the developing world.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Directs wealthier nations to act on the moral responsibility their privilege entails.

paragraphs.text: We call upon all the communities to be tolerant, to reject prejudice based on caste, creed, sect, religion or gender. To ensure freedom and equality for women so that they can flourish. We cannot all succeed when half of us are held back.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Calls communities to the moral action of dismantling prejudice, grounding equality in the logic of collective flourishing.

paragraphs.text: We call upon our sisters around the world to be brave to embrace the strength within themselves and realise their full potential.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Closes the series of 'we call upon' demands by addressing women directly and calling them to moral self-empowerment.

paragraphs.text: Dear brothers and sisters, we want schools and education for every child's bright future. We will continue our journey to our destination of peace and education. No one can stop us. We will speak up for our rights and we will bring change through our voice. We must believe in the power and the strength of our words. Our words can change the whole world, because we are all together, united for the cause of education.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Rallying declaration affirming collective resolve and the transformative moral power of unified voices.

paragraphs.text: And if we want to achieve our goal, then let us empower ourselves with the weapon of knowledge and let us shield ourselves with unity and togetherness.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Frames knowledge and solidarity as the moral weapons with which the audience must arm themselves.

paragraphs.text: Dear brothers and sisters, we must not forget that millions of people are suffering from poverty, injustice and ignorance. We must not forget that millions of children are out of their schools. We must not forget that our sisters and brothers are waiting for a bright, peaceful future.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The anaphoric 'we must not forget' re-anchors the call to action in the ongoing suffering that makes inaction morally inexcusable.

paragraphs.text: So let us wage…so let us wage a global struggle against illiteracy, poverty and terrorism. Let us pick up…let us pick up our books and our pens. They are our most powerful weapons.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: The climactic call to 'wage a global struggle' with books and pens crystallizes the speech's moral imperative in one memorable image.

paragraphs.text: One child, one teacher, one book and one pen can change the world.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The iconic formulation presents the achievable moral ideal—transformative change through the simplest educational tools.

paragraphs.text: Education is the only solution. Education First.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: A final, unambiguous moral declaration that education is not merely desirable but the singular path forward.

paragraphs.text: Thank you. ## Christine Lagarde
paragraphs.comment: Closing acknowledgment followed by a section header for the next speech; not part of Malala's argument.

paragraphs.text: Christine Lagarde (1956-) studied English, law and politics in France and began work as a lawyer in Chicago, USA in 1981, becoming her firm's chairman in 1999. She became France's trade minister in 2005 and in 2007 the country's first female finance minister. Since July 2011, she has been the managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) which seeks to 'foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world'. In 2014, she faced a charge of criminal negligence during her tenure as finance minister. This was over her handling of a €400 million legal battle between the tycoon Bernard Tapie and the bank Crédit Lyonnais over the sale of the sportswear firm Adidas. In July 2016, a French court confirmed that she must stand trial in relation to this charge, which carries a possible jail sentence. In 2014, she was named in Forbes magazine as the fifth most influential woman in the world.
paragraphs.comment: Editorial biography of the next speaker in the anthology; unrelated to Malala's speech.

title: We shall overcome
speaker: Lyndon B. Johnson
summary: Johnson appeals to American moral principles to support voting rights and racial equality.
introduction: President Lyndon B. Johnson addressed a joint session of Congress on March 15, 1965, five days after state troopers on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, used clubs and tear gas to attack peaceful voting rights marchers, an event broadcast on national television that shocked the nation. Johnson, a Texas Democrat who had fought to pass the 1964 Civil Rights Act, now faced the most consequential moment of his presidency: whether to use his political capital to force a voting rights bill through a Congress that included many Southern Democrats bitterly opposed to Black enfranchisement. His decision to adopt the words 'We shall overcome,' the anthem of the civil rights movement, as the title of his address was a deliberate act of solidarity with activists who had been beaten demanding the rights he was now promising to deliver. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 passed within five months.

paragraphs.text: Mr Speaker, Mr President, members of the Congress, I speak tonight for the dignity of man and the destiny of democracy. I urge every member of both parties, Americans of all religions and of all colours, from every section of this country, to join me in that cause.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson opens by invoking the universal values of human dignity and democracy, framing his appeal as transcending party and region.

paragraphs.text: At times, history and fate meet at a single time in a single place to shape a turning-point in man's unending search for freedom.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He places the present moment within a grand historical arc of freedom's progress, elevating its moral stakes.

paragraphs.text: So it was at Lexington and Concord. So it was a century ago at Appomattox. So it was last week in Selma, Alabama.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: By linking Selma to Lexington, Concord, and Appomattox, Johnson places the civil rights struggle within America's most celebrated moral turning points.

paragraphs.text: There, long suffering men and women peacefully protested the denial of their rights as Americans. Many were brutally assaulted. One good man -- a man of God -- was killed.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The specific details of peaceful protesters being brutally assaulted and a 'man of God' killed present Selma as a moral atrocity demanding response.

paragraphs.text: There is no cause for pride in what has happened in Selma. There is no cause for self-satisfaction in the long denial of equal rights of millions of Americans. But there is cause for hope and for faith in our democracy in what is happening here tonight.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Johnson names the shame of Selma and the long denial of rights while pivoting to hope, sustaining outrage while opening toward action.

paragraphs.text: For the cries of pain and the hymns of oppressed people have summoned into convocation all the majesty of great Government -- the Government of the greatest nation on earth.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The 'cries of pain and hymns of oppressed people' frame the government's convening as a response to moral suffering, not mere political calculation.

paragraphs.text: Our mission is at once the oldest and the most basic of this country -- to right wrong, to do justice, to serve man.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson defines the nation's mission in the oldest moral terms—to right wrong, do justice, and serve man—grounding the legislative task in timeless values.

paragraphs.text: In our time we have come to live with the moments of great crisis. Our lives have been marked with debate about great issues, issues of war and peace, issues of prosperity and depression.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He situates the voting rights crisis among other great national challenges, preparing the audience to recognize this as a test of the same moral seriousness.

paragraphs.text: But rarely in any time does an issue bare the secret heart of America itself. Rarely are we met with a challenge, not to our growth or abundance, or our welfare or our security, but rather to the values and the purposes and the meaning of our beloved nation.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson argues this issue uniquely 'bares the secret heart of America,' making it a referendum on the nation's deepest values and purposes.

paragraphs.text: The issue of equal rights for American Negroes is such an issue.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He names the issue plainly—equal rights for American Negroes—establishing it as the central moral question the speech will address.

paragraphs.text: And should we defeat every enemy, and should we double our wealth and conquer the stars, and still be unequal to this issue, then we will have failed as a people and as a nation.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The conditional framing—defeating enemies, doubling wealth, conquering stars yet failing on equality—poses the starkest possible contrast between material success and moral failure.

paragraphs.text: For, with a country as with a person, 'What is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?'
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The biblical quotation equates racial inequality with losing one's soul, framing the moral stakes in the highest possible terms.

paragraphs.text: There is no Negro problem. There is no Southern problem. There is no Northern problem. There is only an American problem.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: By declaring 'There is only an American problem,' Johnson refuses any regional deflection and insists on collective ownership of the injustice.

paragraphs.text: And we are met here tonight as Americans -- not as Democrats or Republicans; we're met here as Americans to solve that problem.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson unifies the audience as Americans rather than partisans, creating a shared identity from which a shared moral obligation follows.

paragraphs.text: This was the first nation in the history of the world to be founded with a purpose. The great phrases of that purpose still sound in every American heart, North and South:
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He roots the argument in America's founding purpose, asserting that the nation's identity is uniquely defined by its stated ideals.

paragraphs.text: 'All men are created equal.' 'Government by consent of the governed.' 'Give me liberty or give me death.'
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: The recitation of founding phrases—'All men are created equal' and 'Give me liberty or give me death'—invokes ideals the audience already accepts as sacred.

paragraphs.text: And those are not just clever words, and those are not just empty theories.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson insists these are not empty words but living promises, reinforcing the moral authority of the founding ideals he is about to apply to the present crisis.

paragraphs.text: In their name Americans have fought and died for two centuries and tonight around the world they stand there as guardians of our liberty risking their lives.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He grounds the ideals in sacrifice—Americans who 'fought and died for two centuries'—making betrayal of those ideals a dishonoring of the fallen.

paragraphs.text: Those words are promised to every citizen that he shall share in the dignity of man. This dignity cannot be found in a man's possessions. It cannot be found in his power or in his position: it really rests on his right to be treated as a man equal in opportunity to all others.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson makes the founding promise explicit: every citizen is guaranteed the dignity of equal treatment and equal opportunity as a matter of right, not charity.

paragraphs.text: It says that he shall share in freedom. He shall choose his leaders, educate his children, provide for his family according to his ability and his merits as a human being.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He unpacks what freedom means concretely—choosing leaders, educating children, providing for family—making the denial of voting rights a denial of life itself.

paragraphs.text: To apply any other test, to deny a man his hopes because of his colour or race or his religion or the place of his birth is not only to do injustice, it is to deny America and to dishonour the dead who gave their lives for American freedom.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Denying rights on the basis of race is named not merely as injustice but as a denial of America and a dishonoring of those who died for American freedom.

paragraphs.text: Our fathers believed that if this noble view of the rights of man was to flourish it must be rooted in democracy. The most basic right of all was the right to choose your own leaders.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Johnson grounds voting rights in the founders' own belief that democracy requires universal suffrage, establishing the right to vote as the bedrock of the American system.

paragraphs.text: The history of this country in large measure is the history of expansion of that right to all of our people. Many of the issues of civil rights are very complex and most difficult. But about this there can and should be no argument: every American citizen must have an equal right to vote.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: After affirming the universal right to vote, Johnson pivots to the 'harsh fact' that Black Americans are systematically denied that right, sharpening the moral contradiction.

paragraphs.text: There is no reason which can excuse the denial of that right. There is no duty which weighs more heavily on us than the duty we have to insure that right. Yet the harsh fact is that in many places in this country men and women are kept from voting simply because they are Negroes.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Johnson insists there is no acceptable excuse for denying the vote and names the denial of this most fundamental right as the nation's weightiest moral failure.

paragraphs.text: Every device of which human ingenuity is capable has been used to deny this right. The Negro citizen may go to register only to be told that the day is wrong, or the hour is late, or the official in charge is absent.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The catalog of specific suppression tactics—wrong day, wrong hour, absent official—makes the systematic denial concrete and undeniable.

paragraphs.text: And if he persists and if he manages to present himself to the registrar, he may be disqualified because he did not spell out his middle name, or because he abbreviated a word on the application. And if he manages to fill out an application, he is given a test.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The escalating sequence of obstacles—middle name, abbreviated words, the application itself—reveals voter suppression as a deliberate labyrinth designed to exclude.

paragraphs.text: The registrar is the sole judge of whether he passes this test. He may be asked to recite the entire Constitution, or explain the most complex provisions of state law.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The registrar as sole judge, demanding full recitation of the Constitution, exposes the arbitrary and humiliating exercise of power over Black citizens.

paragraphs.text: And even a college degree cannot be used to prove that he can read and write. For the fact is that the only way to pass these barriers is to show a white skin.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The blunt conclusion—'the only way to pass these barriers is to show a white skin'—strips the system of any pretense of fairness and names it as pure racial exclusion.

paragraphs.text: Experience has clearly shown that the existing process of law cannot overcome systematic and ingenious discrimination. No law that we now have on the books, and I have helped to put three of them there, can insure the right to vote when local officials are determined to deny it. In such a case, our duty must be clear to all of us.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Having demonstrated that existing laws cannot overcome systematic discrimination, Johnson argues that the duty to act is now clear and unavoidable.

paragraphs.text: The Constitution says that no person shall be kept from voting because of his race or his colour. We have all sworn an oath before God to support and to defend that Constitution. We must now act in obedience to that oath.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Johnson invokes the oath before God to defend the Constitution as the moral and legal mandate that compels Congress to act immediately.

paragraphs.text: On Wednesday, I will send to Congress a law designed to eliminate illegal barriers to the right to vote ...
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: The concrete legislative commitment—sending a voting rights bill to Congress on Wednesday—transforms moral argument into executive action.

paragraphs.text: Outside this chamber is the outraged conscience of a nation, the grave concern of many nations and the harsh judgement of history on our acts.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: The 'outraged conscience of a nation' and 'harsh judgement of history' frame the legislative moment as a moral test watched by the world.

paragraphs.text: But even if we pass this bill the battle will not be over.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Johnson warns that passing the bill is only a beginning, urging sustained commitment beyond the single legislative act.

paragraphs.text: What happened in Selma is part of a far larger movement which reaches into every section and state of America. It is the effort of American Negroes to secure for themselves the full blessings of American life.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: He contextualizes the Selma events within the larger movement for full Black citizenship, framing the struggle as a national aspiration, not a regional conflict.

paragraphs.text: Their cause must be our cause too. Because it's not just Negroes but really it's all of us who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice. And we shall overcome.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Johnson's adoption of 'We shall overcome'—the movement's own anthem—publicly aligns the presidency with the marchers and demands that all Americans share their cause.

paragraphs.text: As a man whose roots go deeply into Southern soil, I know how agonizing racial feelings are. I know how difficult it is to reshape the attitudes and the structure of our society. But a century has passed -- more than one hundred years -- since the Negro was freed.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Speaking personally as a Southerner, Johnson acknowledges the difficulty of change while insisting that a century of delay has exhausted the time for patience.

paragraphs.text: And he is not fully free tonight.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: The stark, isolated declaration—'And he is not fully free tonight'—forces the audience to sit with the unresolved moral failure one hundred years after emancipation.

paragraphs.text: It was more than one hundred years ago that Abraham Lincoln -- a great President of another party -- signed the Emancipation Proclamation. But emancipation is a proclamation and not a fact.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The gap between Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation and the lived reality of Black Americans is named directly: 'emancipation is a proclamation and not a fact.'

paragraphs.text: A century has passed -- more than one hundred years -- since equality was promised, and yet the Negro is not equal.
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: The century-long gap between the promise of equality and the reality of inequality is stated plainly, making the failure of the American ideal concrete and measurable.

paragraphs.text: A century has passed since the day of promise, and the promise is unkept. The time of justice has now come, and I tell you that I believe sincerely that no force can hold it back. It is right in the eyes of man and God that it should come, and when it does, I think that day will brighten the lives of every American.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Johnson declares that the time of justice has now come and that no force can hold it back, framing action not as optional but as the inevitable and righteous tide of history.

paragraphs.text: For Negroes are not the only victims. How many white children have gone uneducated? How many white families have lived in stark poverty? How many white lives have been scarred by fear, because we wasted energy and our substance to maintain the barriers of hatred and terror?
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: By showing that white Americans too have been impoverished and uneducated by the maintenance of racial barriers, Johnson broadens the moral stakes beyond Black suffering alone.

paragraphs.text: And so I say to all of you here and to all in the nation tonight that those who appeal to you to hold on to the past do so at the cost of denying you your future. This great rich, restless country can offer opportunity and education and hope to all -- all, black and white, all, North and South, sharecropper and city dweller.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Johnson calls the entire nation—Black and white, North and South—to reject those who appeal to the past and instead claim the abundant future that equality makes possible.

paragraphs.text: These are the enemies: poverty, ignorance, disease. They are our enemies, not our fellow man, not our neighbour. And these enemies too -- poverty, disease and ignorance -- we shall overcome.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: The speech closes by redefining the true enemies as poverty, ignorance, and disease—not fellow Americans—and repeating 'we shall overcome' as a vow to defeat those enemies together.

title: An ideal for which I am prepared to die
speaker: Nelson Mandela
summary: Mandela defends the ANC's struggle against apartheid and articulates ideals of democratic equality and human dignity.
introduction: Nelson Mandela delivered this four-hour statement from the dock of the Palace of Justice in Pretoria on April 20, 1964, during the Rivonia Trial, proceedings in which he and nine co-defendants faced charges of sabotage and conspiracy to overthrow the apartheid state. The charges carried the death penalty. Mandela, already serving a five-year sentence for leaving the country without a permit, chose not to give sworn testimony but instead delivered a prepared statement directly to the court and to the watching world. He knew the speech might be his last public statement. International pressure from the United Nations, world governments, and anti-apartheid activists was intense, as observers feared the state would execute Mandela and his colleagues. The statement had to accomplish two things simultaneously: offer a full accounting of the ANC's turn to armed resistance, and articulate the moral vision underpinning the struggle in terms that transcended the immediate legal proceedings. Mandela was sentenced to life imprisonment rather than death and served twenty-seven years before his release in 1990.

paragraphs.text: I am the First Accused. I hold a Bachelor's Degree in Arts and practised as an attorney in Johannesburg for a number of years in partnership with Oliver Tambo. I am a convicted prisoner serving five years for leaving the country without a permit and for inciting people to go on strike at the end of May 1961. At the outset, I want to say that the suggestion made by the State in its opening that the struggle in South Africa is under the influence of foreigners or Communists is wholly incorrect. I have done whatever I did, both as an individual and as a leader of my people, because of my experience in South Africa and my own African background, not because of what any outsider might have said.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Establishes credibility and grounds his defense in South African experience, not foreign influence; appeals to law and order values.

paragraphs.text: I admit immediately that I was one of the persons who helped to form Umkhonto we Sizwe, and that I played a prominent role in its affairs until I was arrested in August 1962. I, and the others who started the organization, did so for two reasons. Firstly, we believed that as a result of government policy, violence by the African people had become inevitable, and that unless responsible leadership was given to channel and control the feelings of our people, there would be outbreaks of terrorism which would produce an intensity of bitterness and hostility between the various races of this country which is not produced even by war. Secondly, we felt that without violence there would be no way open to the African people to succeed in their struggle against the principle of white supremacy. All lawful methods of expressing opposition to this principle had been closed by legislation, and we were placed in a position in which we had either to accept a permanent state of inferiority, or to defy the government. We chose to defy the law. We first broke the law in a way which avoided any recourse to violence; when this form was legislated against, and the government resorted to a show of force to crush opposition to its policies, only then did we decide to answer violence with violence.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Documents systemic oppression, closed legal avenues, and forced choice between permanent inferiority or defiance; shows necessity born of desperation.

paragraphs.text: But the violence which we chose to adopt was not terrorism. We who formed Umkhonto were all members of the African National Congress, and had behind us the ANC tradition of nonviolence and negotiation as a means of solving political disputes. We believed that South Africa belonged to all the people who lived in it, and not to one group, be it black or white. We did not want an interracial war, and tried to avoid it to the last. But the hard facts were that fifty years of nonviolence had brought the African people nothing but more and more repressive legislation, and fewer and fewer rights. Four forms of violence were considered -- sabotage, guerrilla warfare, terrorism, and open revolution. We chose to adopt the first method and to exhaust it before making any other decision.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Invokes ANC tradition of nonviolence and shared belief that 'South Africa belonged to all the people'; contrasts their restraint against decades of repression.

paragraphs.text: The initial plan was based on a careful analysis of the political and economic situation of our country. We believed that South Africa depended to a large extent on foreign capital and foreign trade. We felt that planned destruction of power plants, and interference with rail and telephone communications, would tend to scare away capital from the country, make it more difficult for goods from the industrial areas to reach the seaports on schedule, and would in the long run be a heavy drain on the economic life of the country, thus compelling the voters of the country to reconsider their position.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Details the economic exploitation and strategic reasoning; shows moral deliberation in choosing sabotage over more violent alternatives.

paragraphs.text: Attacks on the economic lifelines of the country were to be linked with sabotage on government buildings and other symbols of apartheid. These attacks would serve as a source of inspiration to our people. In addition, they would provide an outlet for those people who were urging the adoption of violent methods and would enable us to give concrete proof to our followers that we had adopted a stronger line and were fighting back against government violence. In addition, if mass action was successfully organized, and mass reprisals taken, we felt that sympathy for our cause would be roused in other countries, and that greater pressure would be brought to bear on the South African government.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Explains intended psychological and material effects of sabotage as calculated response to oppression, not terrorism.

paragraphs.text: This then was the plan. Umkhonto was to perform sabotage, and strict instructions were given to its members that on no account were they to injure or kill people in planning or carrying out operations.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Asserts shared principle that violence must have limits and responsibility; strict orders against killing civilians.

paragraphs.text: Experience convinced us that rebellion would offer the government limitless opportunities for the indiscriminate slaughter of our people, but it was precisely because the soil of South Africa was already drenched with the blood of innocent Africans that we felt it our duty to make preparations as a long-term undertaking to use force in order to defend ourselves against force. If war was inevitable, we wanted the fight to be conducted on terms most favourable to our people. The fight which held out prospects best for us and the least risk of life to both sides was guerrilla warfare. We decided, therefore, in our preparations for the future, to make provision for the possibility of guerrilla warfare. All whites undergo compulsory military training, but no such training was given to Africans. It was in our view essential to build up a nucleus of trained men who would be able to provide the leadership which would be required if guerrilla warfare started ...
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Documents the blood already shed by innocents and justifies defensive preparation; appeals to self-preservation as moral duty.

paragraphs.text: I turn now to my own position. I have denied that I am a Communist, and I think that in the circumstances I am obliged to state exactly what my political beliefs are. I have always regarded myself, in the first place, as an African patriot. I am attracted by the idea of a classless society, an attraction which springs partly from Marxist reading and partly from my admiration of the structure and organization of early African societies in this country. The land, then the main means of production, belonged to the tribe. There were no rich or poor and there was no exploitation.
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Claims identity as African patriot and appeals to universal ideals: classless society, dignity, early African communalism without exploitation.

paragraphs.text: Yes, I have been influenced by Marxist thought, but so have other leaders such as Gandhi, Nehru, Nkrumah, and Nasser. We all accept the need for some form of socialism to enable our people to catch up with the advanced countries of this world and to overcome their legacy of extreme poverty. But this does not mean we are Communists, or even Marxists. Indeed, for my own part, I believe that it is open to debate whether the Communist Party has any specific role to play at this particular stage of our political struggle. The basic task at the present moment is the removal of race discrimination and the attainment of democratic rights on the basis of the Freedom Charter. Insofar as that party furthers this task, I welcome its assistance. I realize that it is one of the means by which people of all races can be drawn into our struggle ...
paragraphs.label: Establish Shared Moral Ground
paragraphs.comment: Bridges Marxist thought to universal democratic and socialist goals shared by Gandhi, Nehru, Nkrumah; denies communism while affirming shared aspirations.

paragraphs.text: Our fight is against real, and not imaginary hardships, or, to use the language of the State Prosecutor, 'so-called hardships'. We fight against two features which are the hallmarks of African life in South Africa, and which are entrenched by legislation which we seek to have repealed. These features are poverty and lack of human dignity, and we do not need Communists, or so-called 'agitators', to teach us about these things.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Asserts real hardship (poverty, lack of dignity) is self-evident without external agitation; rooted in lived African experience.

paragraphs.text: The whites enjoy what may well be the highest standard of living in the world, whilst Africans live in poverty and misery. Forty per cent of the Africans live in hopelessly overcrowded and, in some cases, drought-stricken reserves, where soil erosion and the overworking of the soil make it impossible for them to live properly off the land. Thirty per cent are labourers, labour tenants, and squatters on white farms and work and live under conditions similar to those of the serfs of the Middle Ages. The other thirty per cent live in towns where they have developed economic and social habits which bring them closer, in many respects, to white standards. Yet forty-six per cent of all African families in Johannesburg do not earn enough to keep them going.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Provides stark statistical contrasts: whites enjoy highest living standards while Africans suffer poverty, restricted land access, and labor conditions like serfdom.

paragraphs.text: The complaint of Africans, however, is not only that they are poor and whites are rich, but that the laws which are made by the whites are designed to preserve this situation. There are two ways to break out of poverty. The first is by formal education, and the second is by the worker acquiring a greater skill at his work and thus higher wages. As far as Africans are concerned, both these avenues of advancement are deliberately curtailed by legislation.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Shows legal system itself designed to perpetuate inequality; whites make laws protecting white advantage; systematically blocks education and skill advancement.

paragraphs.text: The present Government has always sought to hamper Africans in their search for education. There is compulsory education for all white children at virtually no cost to their parents, be they rich or poor. Similar facilities are not provided for African children. In 1960--61, the per capita government spending on African students at state-funded schools was estimated at R12.46. In the same year, the per capita spending on white children in the Cape Province (which are the only figures available to me) was R144.57. The present Prime Minister said during the debate on the Bantu Education Bill in 1953: 'When I have control of Native education, I will reform it so that Natives will be taught from childhood to realize that equality with Europeans is not for them ... People who believe in equality are not desirable teachers for Natives. When my Department controls Native education, it will know for what class of higher education a Native is fitted, and whether he will have a chance in life to use his knowledge.'
paragraphs.label: Contrast with Moral Ideal
paragraphs.comment: Cites apartheid government's own words about denying African equality; reveals contradiction between claimed civilization and deliberate subjugation.

paragraphs.text: The other main obstacle to the economic advancement of the Africans is the industrial colour bar by which all the better jobs of industry are reserved for whites only. Moreover, Africans are not allowed to form trade unions, which have recognition under the Industrial Conciliation Act. The Government often answers its critics by saying that Africans in South Africa are economically better off than the inhabitants of the other countries in Africa. Our complaint is not that we are poor by comparison with people in other countries, but that we are poor by comparison with white people in our own country, and that we are prevented by legislation from altering this imbalance.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Documents industrial color bar, denial of union rights, and systemic prevention of economic mobility despite claims of relative progress.

paragraphs.text: Hundreds and thousands of Africans are thrown into gaol each year under pass laws. Even worse than this is the fact that pass laws keep husband and wife apart and lead to the breakdown of family life.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Catalogs pass laws that separate families and destroy family life; demonstrates cascading moral destruction beyond economic harm.

paragraphs.text: Poverty and the breakdown of family life have secondary effects. Children wander about the streets of the townships because they have no schools to go to, or no money to enable them to go to school, or no parents at home to see that they go to school because both parents, if there be two, have to work to keep the family alive. This leads to a breakdown in moral standards, to an alarming rise in illegitimacy and to growing violence which erupts not only politically but everywhere. Life in the townships is dangerous; there is not a day that goes by without somebody being stabbed or assaulted. And violence is carried out of the townships into the white living areas. People are afraid to walk alone in the streets after dark. House-breakings and robberies are increasing despite the fact that the death sentence can now be imposed for such offences. Death sentences cannot cure the festering sore. The only cure is to alter the conditions under which the Africans are forced to live, and to meet their legitimate grievances.
paragraphs.label: Demonstrate Moral Outrage
paragraphs.comment: Shows secondary consequences: broken families produce broken communities, crime, violence; systemic violence begets social violence throughout society.

paragraphs.text: We want to be part of the general population, and not confined to living in our ghettos. African men want to have their wives and children to live with them where they work, and not to be forced into an unnatural existence in men's hostels. Our women want to be left with their men folk, and not to be left permanently widowed in the Reserves. We want to be allowed out after 11 p.m. and not to be confined to our rooms like little children. We want to be allowed to travel in our own country, and seek work where we want to, and not where the Labour Bureau tells us to. We want a just share in the whole of South Africa; we want security and a stake in society.
paragraphs.label: Call to Moral Action
paragraphs.comment: Lists concrete demands for dignity: freedom of movement, family reunion, political equality; positions rights as basic human needs.

paragraphs.text: Above all, my lord, we want equal political rights, because without them our disabilities will be permanent.
